The intent could be to evoke the godly status that Van Gogh had 
risen to, and perhaps the artist himself wishes that one day he 
will achieve that. The human figure dominates Sen's artwork and 
recurrent subject in Sen's works is his depiction of scenes from 
everyday urban life. His style of representation is influenced by 
his exposure to Western Modern art, and has traces of cubism. He 
uses two dimensional, structured planes but still creates an 
illusion of voluptuousness. 
A painter, illustrator, tutor and writer, Paritosh Sen has been a 
part of the world of Indian art, for close to four decades now. 
Founder of the Calcutta Group in the 1940s, prior to the 
existence of a Progressive Artists group, his art is rendered 
from a cynical and detached perspective, which is typically Sen's 
viewpoint.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
On arrival in Paris there was a greater emphasis towards a hard-
edged geometry, where the house acted as he transitional motif. 
Gade allowed his conceptual framework to discipline the 
intuition. His scientific background led him to express his 
colour sense through a range of minimalized and simplified forms, 
(the motif of buildings and houses served Gade). A core member of 
the Progressive Artists group, Gade came into his own only as 
late as the 1950's.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: In the 1960s, the search for a national cultural identity through Neo-tantric Art, a term coined to denote a form of abstraction developed by a small group of Indian artists. Among them was, Gulam Rasool Santosh, who experimented with neo-tantric mysticism and formalist abstraction. The aniconic and notational drawings of the Tantric Yantra, originally ritual designs for Tantric meditation, underwent a sea- change in his hand: the triangle became a pyramid, the circle a solid sphere, the square a cube which, in further constructivist elaboration, assumed the shape of a gem, emanating light. Born in Srinagar, Kashmir, Santosh was also an acclaimed mystic poet in Kashmiri and wrote profusely in Urdu.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Capturing the depth of human emotions has always be the strong 
point of leading photographer Raghu Rai's work. A versatile 
photographer, Raghu Rai has worked with some of the major news 
journals in India and abroad. His coverage of the Bhopal gas 
tragedy for the India Today, won him both critical acclaim as 
well as the World Press Photo Award in the same year. In a heart 
wrenching series of photographs, Rai arrests the chaos and 
paranoia of the situation as it appeared before him. In later 
years, his iconic photographs have become part of museum 
collections, having attained the status of national treasures.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Anjolie Ela Menon has been painting for over five decades, 
evolving a technique reminiscent of the old masters in its sheer 
feeling for depth and space. Her thematic of her art revolves 
around the traditional families of Kerala, or the domestic 
structure within middle class homes. Trademark aspects of Ela 
Menon's work are her surreal figures with deep-set haunted eyes. 
Within these unsettling compositions the landscape of Kerala is 
also often made visible.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A sensitive artist, Reddy evolved a unique vision of his own, 
creating complex compositions, realistic and expressionistic 
portraits, still-lifes and impressionistic landscapes. His later 
works are abstract, often revealing a tantric influence with folk 
motifs and symbols, and a synthesis of almost contrary forms. As 
an artist, Reddy interprets the traditional Tantra philosophy and 
at the same time deals with contemporary themes. For both neo-
tantric artists and Western modernists, the tension between the 
spiritual and the material found expression through symbols that 
defied particular iconographic or culturally-grounded systems and 
instead evoked broader universal expressions of spirituality, 
patterns in the universe, and sense perception. Reddy's use of 
symbols, connection to a spiritual system in tantra, and 
interpretation of sound all play into similar ideas. 

Reddy came from a poor family of agriculturists, who strongly 
opposed his choice to make art his professional practice. Defying 
his family's wishes, Reddy joined the J. J. School of Arts, 
Bombay to study painting under a scholarship. Here he was also 
trained in mural design and was acquainted with the Rajput and 
Pahari miniature styles.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Senathipathi is known for his representations of Indian Gods and Goddesses. Though he leans on Indian mythology for his subjects he infuses them with the spirit of the human by rooting his works in contemporary times. It is this amalgamation of two diverse qualities that create a sense of drama and infuses the works with a fresh perspective. The artist is also versatile in using metal relief for his subjects.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A photo-realist portrait of a Marathi woman, likely to have been 
painted in the early 1900's when Western techniques of academic 
realism were being instituted in India. The tactile quality of 
the skin, the folds of the saree, and the iconography of her 
ethnicity have been exceptionally captured in this portrait.
info.Detailed Description:
Despite the fascination the Mughal and Rajput painters felt for 
European naturalism, its systematic introduction in India would not 
have been possible without the ambitious art policy initiated by 
the Raj in the 1850's. Indeed one of the most powerful effects of 
the British Raj was on artistic taste.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A performative painting, the picture shows Radha located 
centrally striking an elaborate dance pose, while Krishna 
intimately engages with her.
info.Detailed Description:
An intricate painting with gold inlay, this painting can be attributed to the Surpur style of miniature painting. 'Surpur miniature' is a unique style of painting that has its provenance in Surpur, a small town about 109 km from Gulbarga. 

Surpur still has splendid mansions (though in ruins), and many maths and temples. It is on the walls of these ruins that Surpur murals are found. This style of painting can be considered an offshoot of the Vijayanagara style and it shares similarities with the more established Mysore and Thanjavur painting in terms of gesso technique and the rendering of gold leaf with embedded semi-precious stones. The thematic content adheres to mythology and Vedic themes.

Surpurs place throughout the entire existence of Indian workmanship has been established to a great extent being the focal point of a variation of the Mysore style of painting. Crafted by past experts of workmanship like Banayya Garudadri.
It spread incredible consciousness of the complexities of fine art. 

Yet additionally of the remaining of Surpur with regards to conventional Indian craftsmanship. The style and the topics (scenes from the Indian sagas) when investigated are, in some sense, a subordinate of this impact.

It can very well be viewed as a tribute to this withering work of art which has hardly any living professionals today.

Surpur has now been rechristened Shorapur Town. What is more, it is an able illustration of the work.

Surpur style and the Vijayanagara style

The Surpur style of painting is considered a branch of the Vijayanagara style.

The craftsmanship prospered under the support of rulers for around two centuries, especially during the rule of Immadi Venkatapa Nayaka and Mummadi Venkatapa Nayaka. Surpur representing much settled Mysore

The current day Surpur style paintings owe their cause to the wall paintings found in the dividers of demolished manors and sanctuaries of Surpur taluk in the Yadgir area.

The style is like the more settled Mysore (presently Mysuru) and Tanjore styles of painting as far as the gesso work and the delivering of gold leaf with inserted semi-valuable stones. The topical substance clings to folklore and Vedic subjects, for example, the ashtadikpalas or the watchmen of eight headings.

While a few artistic creations were made out of appreciation for lords and aristocrats, a few canvases were utilized to decorate real photos.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Devyani Krishna's introspection did not demand the use of 
socially relevant comments or the figurative idiom. Her 
printmaking journey reflected a rare feminine attempt to fuse the 
ancient symbolism of various religions with the contemporary 
demand of self-awareness and its scientific inclinations. This 
print is part of a series called 'Allah', where she abstracted 
the calligraphic use of the Persian letters, to create a form to 
an aniconic religion.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
"I start a painting with a vague thought - it could be based on 
my everyday experience, or something else altogether - and from 
there a story begins to take shape. I fill my work with gaps and 
loose ends; I want to lead and mislead the viewer. Ambiguity 
makes a picture very exciting." In his formative years he was 
really interested in rhymes and chants from the past, as well as 
children's tales and comic books. At that time his work was very 
expressionistic, but when he lost faith in this, he began to 
experiment with mark-making and the idea of chanting with forms - 
"this was a fresh and exciting approach". Harsha began assembling 
distinct individuals, characters or forms in the same picture 
frame and observing their interrelationships as a way of 
portraying the reality of everyday life. "My work is not just 
trying to achieve a visual perfection but is a journey into these 
individual forms within a large panorama."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Patel's work reveals a certain single-mindedness in this respect 
that is visible even in recent works, l;ike image in search of 
images. Early in the 60's Jeram, Patel starts experimenting with 
incision created on wood through the action of a blowlamp. The 
scorched, pitted surface is then worked over with enamel paint, 
sometimes coupled with plastic emulsion, tin sheets and nails. 
Patel's statement is revealing of his aim; "Nobody can create 
anything, the only thing one can do is destroy, things". These 
works reveal the quality of a primal encounter between the 
artists subjectivity and the material in a process that has 
overtones of painfully erotic combat.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Patel's work reveals a certain single-mindedness in this respect 
that is visible even in recent works, l;ike image in search of 
images. Early in the 60's Jeram, Patel starts experimenting with 
incision created on wood through the action of a blowlamp. The 
scorched, pitted surface is then worked over with enamel paint, 
sometimes coupled with plastic emulsion, tin sheets and nails. 
Patel's statement is revealing of his aim; "Nobody can create 
anything, the only thing one can do is destroy, things". These 
works reveal the quality of a primal encounter between the 
artists subjectivity and the material in a process that has 
overtones of painfully erotic combat.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Somnath Hore taught at Indian Art College and Delhi Polytechnic 
before coming to teach at Kala Bhavan Santiniketan. Known as a 
painter-sculptor Hore's work reflects a sensitivity towards 
'line' that evokes an honesty and humaneness. His sketches of the 
human body show an understanding of the emotions undergone in 
pain and joy with simultaneous intensity. His "Wound Series", 
exemplify the artists skill of portraying inner pain through 
delicately sketched human figures. A master print maker, Hore's 
etchings, unlike any other depict the impact of national events 
of calamities on his own psyche. "Art deals with form. When 
painting I had to think in terms of colour, space, some sort of 
spontaneity, so as to create some kind of aesthetic pursuit."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Main Material: Inkjet on smooth fine art paper

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Detailed Description:
In 1929, Amrita Sher-Gil joined the Ecole des Beaux Arts in 
Paris, and developed therein a visual language characteristic of 
'Western' sensibilities, with its naturalism and textured 
application of paint. 
By the mid 1930's, Sher-Gil's style of painting underwent a 
radical change where the colours, textures, vibrancy and the 
earthiness of the people had a deep impact on the young artist. 
In this painting we see a reclining nude female figure looking at 
the viewer. The tone of her skin, hair, and eyes reveal her
European lineage. The artist has painted the figure in a Western 
realist style, which is reflective of Sher-Gil's European art 
schooling. 
An element of lust is portrayed through the robust body, the 
reclining posture as well as the model's inviting gaze.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Abdur Rahman Chughtai, was one of the prominent orientalists from outside Bengal, who created his own unique, distinctive painting style influenced by Mughal art, Miniature painting, Art Nouveau and Islamic art traditions. He is considered 'the first significant modern Muslim artist from South Asia', and the national artist of Pakistan. Early on in his career Chughtai did a series of wash and tempera on paper, which exuded the visual language of the Bengal School. The characters in the painting, most often couples, were portrayed as if in a state of trance. They were drawn gracefully, with a lyrical quality to every line. The features of these characters bear a string resemblance to the mural paintings at Ajanta, which were a strong influence on Chughtai's artistic sensibilities. By the 1940s he had created his own style, strongly influenced by Islamic art traditions, but retaining a feel of Art Nouveau. His subject matter was drawn from legends, folklore and history of the Indo-Islamic world, as well as Punjab, Persia and the world of the Mughals.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Abdur Rahman Chughtai, was one of the prominent orientalists from 
outside Bengal, who created his own unique, distinctive painting 
style influenced by Mughal art, miniature painting, Art Nouveau 
and Islamic art traditions. He is considered 'the first 
significant modern Muslim artist from South Asia', and the 
national artist of Pakistan. Early on in his career Chughtai did

language of the Bengal School. The characters in the painting,

They were drawn gracefully, with a lyrical quality to every line. 
The features of these characters bear a string resemblance to the

Chughtai's artistic sensibilities. By the 1940s he had created

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This delicately portrayed scene, depicts a crow and a cow, possibly 
in conversation, aside a thatched house. A faint hazy orange circle 
can be the setting sun. The medium of pastels, lends itself to give 
the painting a feeling of twilight. The greenish-blue horizon 
suggests that scene attempts to capture the time of early dawn.
info.Detailed Description:
Leader of the Revivalist Movement in the field of Modern Indian 
Painting in Bengal, Abanindranath Tagore is also credited with a 
key contribution towards ushering in the renaissance in Indian 
painting. Abanindranath's inner urge for liberating Indian art 
was further inspired by Okakura, a great Japanese artist and art-
critic who came to India with Swami Vivekananda. His work has a 
great delicacy of feeling, unity of concept, a highly sensitive 
range of color, tone, texture and poetic depth. His work was a 
mixture of traditionalism and innovation. He aimed at comparing 
nature in its transient forms and produce an image part object, 
part sensuous, both transposed into each other. But his vision on 
nature was always poetic, as was his personal form of expression.


In Abanindranth's pictures we see, for instance his adherence to 
the creation of Rasa (mood, flavor, taste) as being one of the 
ultimate aim of art. His use of analogy and suggestion to evoke 
emotion is very strong. Abanindranath Tagore continued to paint 
from the mental vision typical of Indian art, and did not use 
models. He has also categorically stated: "For let us not forget 
that it is the artist and his creation that comes first, and then 
the law giver and his codes of art. Art is not for the 
justification of the Silpa Sastra, but the Sastra for the 
elucidation of art."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An elegant blending of myth and reality, this painting 
depicts a cow in profile against the entrance gate of a 
house. The cows head is lifted upwards towards an image of 
Krishna who appears to be holding a pot. The well known 
image of baby Krishna, stealing butter from an earthen 
pot, while a cow waited alongside, has been evocatively 
replicated within the mundane act of a cow walking past an 
entrance gate.
info.Detailed Description:

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A series that inspired many of the Bengal School artist, Natri Puja 
has been painted often by the artist's student, Nandalal Bose. 
This painting shows a woman, holding an Ektara, and instrument used 
by the Baoul singers of Bengal.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In 1929, Amrita Sher-Gil joined the Ecole des Beaux Arts in 
Paris, and developed therein a visual language characteristic of 
'Western' sensibilities, with its naturalism and textured 
application of paint. 
By the mid 1930's, Sher-Gil's style of painting underwent a 
radical change where the colours, textures, vibrancy and the 
earthiness of the people had a deep impact on the young artist. 
In this painting one can see two seated Mendicants. Both 
the figures are adorned in saffron robes. The Mendicant 
in the foreground holds a cloth bag strung over his 
shoulder. Both figures wear a Rudrashimala. It is evident that 
Sher-Gil's transformation of style is complete by this period, 
and the focus is now not so much on realistic portrayal, but 
thematic and colour scheme. As Geeta Kapur has written, Amrita 
Sher-Gil had to 'act out the paradox of the oriental subject in 
the body of a woman designated as Eurasian - a hybrid body of 
unusual beauty'

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In 1929, Amrita Sher-Gil joined the Ecole des Beaux Arts in 
Paris, and developed therein a visual language characteristic of 
'Western' sensibilities, with its naturalism and textured 
application of paint. 
By the mid 1930's, Sher-Gil's style of painting underwent a 
radical change where the colours, textures, vibrancy and the 
earthiness of the people had a deep impact on the young artist. 
In this painting two elephants are seen standing side by side in 
the surroundings of leafless trees. The elephant in the 
foreground is 
eating leaves from a fallen branch at it's feet while the other 
is holding sugar-cane stems
in it's trunk. In the background we can see two birds seated 
on the branches of a tree. The elephants although unchained, 
appear domesticated in their stance, and manner of eating. It is 
evident that Sher-Gil's transformation of style is complete by 
this period, and the focus is now not so much on realistic 
portrayal, but thematic and colour scheme.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In 1929, Amrita Sher-Gil joined the Ecole des Beaux Arts in 
Paris, and developed therein a visual language characteristic of 
'Western' sensibilities, with its naturalism and textured 
application of paint. 
By the mid 1930's, Sher-Gil's style of painting underwent a 
radical change where the colours, textures, vibrancy and the 
earthiness of the people had a deep impact on the young artist. 
In this painting we can see a group of three musicians with their 
instruments, seated on the ground. In the foreground is a 
seated 
male figure with a garland of 
orange 
flowers around his neck, holding a string instrument, similar to 
a tanpura. In the background we see another 
musician playing a percussion instrument. All three figures have 
distinctly white turbans, usually worn by the Sikh community. It 
is evident that Sher-Gil's transformation of style is complete by 
this period, and the focus is now not so much on realistic 
portrayal, but thematic and colour scheme.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The practice of printmaking as a fine art medium gained immense 
popularity with the establishment of Kala Bhavan founded by 
Rabindranath Tagore in 1919, wherein new styles of printmaking 
were explored through an organization called the 'Bichitra Club'. 
A prominent member of this club was artist Mukul Chandra Dey, who 
was the first Indian artist to go abroad in the 1920's to learn 
graphic art.
Indian painter-engraver Mukul Chandra Dey, was an important 
personality of his time. A student of Santiniketan School during 
the early years of the 20th century, he left his mark as a 
pioneer of dry point-etching in India. Having interacted closely 
with such Japanese masters as Yokoyama Taikan, Shimomura Kanzan, 
his skill with lines, and familiarity and exposure with Eastern 
printmaking traditions such as the Ukiyo-e prints, widened. 
Dey used the copper plate, and print surfaces like a sketch book, 
which he would re work at a later stage and make prints of. Some 
of the thematics that recur in his work are rural landscapes, 
mythical narratives, festivals, and the indigenous people of 
Bengals; the Santhals. His prints of people often capture the 
graceful movement of limbs, and have been referred to as rather 
idyllic and romantic. His landscapes though are exquisitely 
portrayed spaces, always maintaining an ambivalence between man 
and nature, real and mythical.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Gaganendranath Tagore's landscapes are exceptionally emotive, in 
that they create a feeling of what the artist attempts to 
express. His earliest sketches and landscapes date back to 1905. 
Inspired by Japanese artist Yokoyama Taikan, Gaganendranath's 
landscapes achieve the right blend of capturing Bengal's vast 
landscapes and romanticizing them. This painting 'Rainy Season', 
evokes the quality of torrential monsoons, and exemplifies the 
artists' mastery over the Japanese wash technique. 
Gaganendranath's  interest in life and later art, was limited to 
and conditioned by his love for everything swadeshi (native).

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Asit Kumar Haldar was born in Jorasanko, a grand-nephew of 
Rabindranath. He designed sets and introduced alpana patterns as 
a form of decoration. He also illustrated a limited edition of 
Gitanjali. Perhaps the most significant contribution came when 
he, along with some other artists, was commissioned by the Indian 
Society of London to copy the paintings in the Ajanta Caves. The 
technique of painting murals and narrating a tale with the brush 
were something a new experience. Enriched, Haldar incorporated 
these into his work to achieve a wonderful life-like effect and 
his canvases attracted worldwide attention. Haldar worked with 
equal ease in oil, tempera, watercolors and a special technique 
that he developed called 'lacit'-lacquered painting on wood. 
Drawing upon the rich cultural heritage of India, Haldar painted 
a whole series of 32 paintings based on the Buddha. Thirty 
canvases formed a collection of episodes from Indian history and 
he also illustrated Omar Khayyam's verses.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sunayani Devi, considered as a primitivist, was born to a family 
of talented writers and painters. Her uncle was Rabindranath 
Tagore and her older brothers were Abanindranath and 
Gaganendranath. From the start her paintings have been considered 
bold, original, resembling ancient Jain paintings in their 
hieratic quality. While her initial style was very similar to 
Abanindranath's, employing the wash technique to its fullest, her 
later paintings, reflected an ideation arising from the encounter 
with village clay dolls that often adorned urban homes, and 
Kalighat pats. The modernist discourse of primitive simplicity 
and the nationalist discourse of cultural authenticity come 
together in the image of Sunayani Devi as a nationalist artist. 
Critical reviews of her paintings, have called her a nave 
painter, who used folk motifs with immense charm and feeling.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
His work, reinforced by a `here and now` understanding and 
awareness of contemporary culture, borrows effortlessly from 
various disciplines, including literature and design, and time 
periods. Bose pays as much attention to form as he does to 
conceptual and/or contextual concerns. Startling planes of flat 
color juxtaposed against skillful, almost photographic, 
representations of identifiable persona, imbue the work with an 
`international` sensibility. Bose admits to combining western 
image-making techniques (such as the installation) with the 
vernacular, in a bid to arrive at an idiom that is entirely 
contemporary and brisk. 

In an earlier interview, he has said: "I refine my color to 
brightness. I have learnt this usage from the alternately subdued 
and lavish color codes of Indian ceremonies and ritual 
performances; the costumes, the gestures of enactment..."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Mohan Samant studied Basholi miniature painting under M. Palsikar 
in his early artistic endevours. In the 50s, Samant joined the 
Progressive Artists' Group (PAG). While his fellow PAGs took 
their inspiration predominately from Paris, Samant explored the 
imagery of Egyptian funerary wall drawings, Ajanta murals and 
Rajput miniatures, establishing a range of primeval images in his 
work.
He describes his art as "almost like installation art; only 
difference being that my installation is within my frame." His 
paintings are primarily abstract, but retain figurative aspects 
that often recreate mythic narratives. One of the most intriguing 
aspects of Samant's paintings is his use of texture: manipulation 
of paint materials with sand and glue in the early 1960's, paper 
cutouts attached to the canvas in the 1970's and the application 
of wire drawings in the 1980's.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Asit Kumar Haldar was born in Jorasanko, a grand-nephew of 
Rabindranath. He designed sets and introduced alpana patterns as 
a form of decoration. He also illustrated a limited edition of 
Gitanjali. Perhaps the most significant contribution came when 
he, along with some other artists, was commissioned by the Indian 
Society of London to copy the paintings in the Ajanta Caves. The 
technique of painting murals and narrating a tale with the brush 
were something a new experience. Enriched, Haldar incorporated 
these into his work to achieve a wonderful life-like effect and 
his canvases attracted worldwide attention. Haldar worked with 
equal ease in oil, tempera, watercolors and a special technique 
that he developed called 'lacit'-lacquered painting on wood. 
Drawing upon the rich cultural heritage of India, Haldar painted 
a whole series of 32 paintings based on the Buddha. Thirty 
canvases formed a collection of episodes from Indian history and 
he also illustrated Omar Khayyam's verses.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The Daniell's were among the first wave of British artist's 
working in India and the views they brought back to Britain were 
novel and exciting. Another excellent example of perspective and 
depth, this 
lithographic print shows the gateway of the Sher Shah's fort in a 
diagonal. In the foreground, is a man riding a camel towards the 
gate. On his right is a dilapidated building with overgrown 
weeds and plants that has a towering presence. While the 
artist is also showing the might 
of Sher Shah's army in the depiction of the solid wall of the 
gate way, he contrasts it with showing cracked walls and a 
surrounding of ruins. The fascination of India is evident in the 
way this landscape print has been romanticized, blending the 
artist's desire to capture the Indian 'country-side' with a 
'white-man's' requirement to document the 'Orient'.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In this art work we see an abstract drawing of seven figures 
juxtaposed in the hilly background.  Tagore never hesitated to 
daub and smear coloured Ink on Paper to give life to his 
disquieting range of subjects.
Although he was untrained as an artist and sometimes referred to 
his paintings as foundlings, painting also made Rabindranath more 
observant and sensitive to the visible world. In these landscape 
paintings done at the evening of his life he more often shows 
nature bathed in the evening light; with radiant skies and forms 
coagulating into ominous silhouettes they invoke mystery and 
foreboding silence.
info.Detailed Description:
Rabindranath Tagore's artistic adventure began with doodles that 
turned crossed-out words and lines into images that assumed 
expressive and sometimes grotesque forms. Many of them represent 
animals, but they are seldom of the real ones we know; more often 
they represent what he has described as 'a probable animal that 
had unaccountably missed its chance of existence' or 'a bird that 
only can soar in our dreams'. While Rabindranath Tagore did not 
acquire technical skill before he began to paint, the resemblance 
to the state of mind of a child is far more obvious.  If this 
comparison with the impulses of a child painter be significant, 
to any extent, the paintings of Rabindranath Tagore may be called 
a sophisticated child art, much more accurately than similar work 
of the many advanced artists, who have surrendered themselves to 
the methods of child art.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting by Gaganendranath Tagore has been influenced by 
Japanese wash technique.  The work depicts landscapes with a 
major portion of the composition dedicated to the sky.  The use 
of tempera adds a gentle fragile quality to the landscapes.
Gaganendranath Tagore's landscapes are exceptionally emotive, in 
that they create a feeling of what the artist attempts to 
express. His earliest sketches and landscapes date back to 1905. 
Inspired by Japanese artist Yokoyama Taikan, Gaganendranath's 
landscapes achieve the right blend of capturing Bengal's vast 
landscapes and romanticizing them. 
Gaganendranath's  interest in life and later art, was limited to 
and conditioned by his love for everything swadeshi (native).

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Kshitindranath Majumdar was an influential figure of the Bengal 
School of Art which flourished between 1905 and 1920. He 
restricted himself to Vaishnavite and literary themes, evolving a 
mannered style in which languid, elongated figures generally 
appear against simple backgrounds with trees and shrubs. In this 
painting, influences from the paintings at Ajanta and Far Eastern 
techniques are evident.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Haren Das was born in a small town called Dinajpur in, what is 
today Bangladesh, but was trained in Graphic arts in Kolkata. He 
worked as a teacher, and introduced line engraving and etching 
into the art curriculum of the Government College of Arts and 
Crafts, thus laying the foundation for print making and graphic 
art education in India.  Most of his works, especially his 
woodcuts and engravings, captured rural, pastoral Bengal, or 
laborers and the farming community at work. Despite using 
restrain and economy, Das has managed to offer a glimpse of a 
Bengal that no longer exists. Most of his work is a nostalgic 
reflection into a childhood and a youth spent at Dinajpur. In his 
works, the artist depicts man as part of nature, an individual 
who lives in harmony with the elements surrounding him.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Renowned art historian, W.G.Archer said. "His pictures have given 
something new to Modern art. They begin part of a fusion of 
Western ideas with an ancient and very different tradition."
His painting trees, reveals his intense understanding of colour, 
where he is able to fuse a Western method of colour application, 
into a thematic that comes closer to home, through his 
composition. Following in the footsteps of fellow expatriate, 
Francis Newton Souza, painter Avinash Chandra left India for 
Britain in 1956, Three years later, he became the first Indian 
British artist exhibited at Tate Britain, in London.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A stunning portrait of a woman in side profile, looking down and 
away from the viewer. The central portion of this painting 
depicts a large, flamboyant pink flower that is contrasted by the 
mood of solitude that this painting evokes. The adherence to Rasa 
(mood, flavor, taste), is very evident here. The painting 
faintly resembles Henry Matisse's portrait of Madame Matisse, in 
its characteristics, and colour palette. However the composition, 
and stylistic treatment is starkly different.
info.Detailed Description:
In Abanindranth's pictures we see, for instance his adherence to 
the creation of Rasa (mood, flavor, taste) as being one of the 
ultimate aim of art. His use of analogy and suggestion to evoke 
emotion is very strong. Abanindranath Tagore continued to paint 
from the mental vision typical of Indian art, and did not use 
models. He has also categorically stated: "For let us not forget 
that it is the artist and his creation that comes first, and then 
the law giver and his codes of art. Art is not for the 
justification of the Silpa Sastra, but the Sastra for the 
elucidation of art."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting of a hen, caught in motion scampering towards the 
viewer. Abanindranath's work was a mixture of traditionalism and 
innovation. He aimed at comparing nature in its transient forms 
and produce an image part object, part sensuous, both transposed 
into each other. But his vision on nature was always poetic, as 
was his personal form of expression.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting is a study of nature, that focuses on the climate 
and well as external emotion. The atmospheric effects have been 
elegantly captured through the use of Tempera. His work was a 
mixture of traditionalism and innovation. He aimed at comparing 
nature in its transient forms and produce an image part object, 
part sensuous, both transposed into each other. But his vision on 
nature was always poetic, as was his personal form of expression.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A master of landscape, and scenery painting, this artwork 
successfully captures the countryside of Bengal, the calm weather, 
and the idyllic mood that has been conveyed through mere tactility. 
A thatched roof house with a chimney is shown amidst the open space 
of the countryside.
info.Detailed Description:

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Another portrait, this time of a man, in side profile. From his 
appearance and attire, he could very well be a Santhal man. The 
anatomy of the facial structure has been the focus, along with an 
attempt to capture the character of the man.
info.Detailed Description:

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting depicts the portrait of a woman, holding an object 
that resembles the back of a sword. Titled wine, woman and war, the 
artist is evoking the warring capacity of the indigenous people, 
capturing the confidence, and authoritarian air of their community 
through this woman.
info.Detailed Description: Leader of the Revivalist Movement in the field of Modern Indian Painting in Bengal, Abanindranath Tagore is also credited with a key contribution towards ushering in the renaissance in Indian painting. In Abanindranth's pictures, we see, for instance, his adherence to the creation of Rasa (mood, flavor, taste) as being one of the ultimate aim of art.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A sketch of Rabindranath, robes around his head, a monk-like 
beard, seated with his eyes closed. This outline sketch shows 
Abanindranath's skill over realistic drawing. Abanindranath's 
inner urge for liberating Indian art was further inspired by 
Okakura, a great Japanese artist and art-critic who came to India 
with Swami Vivekananda. 
His work has a great delicacy of feeling, unity of concept, a 
highly sensitive range of color, tone, texture and poetic depth. 
His work was a mixture of traditionalism and innovation.
info.Detailed Description:

Painting in Bengal, Abanindranath Tagore is also credited with a

painting. Abanindranath's inner urge for liberating Indian art 
was further inspired by Okakura, a great Japanese artist and art-
critic who came to India with Swami Vivekananda.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An attempt to capture the everyday, this painting is filled with 
emotion through sheer texturing. The act of departing, the 
eagerness of the vacation, is visible on the man's expression, and 
the arch that has been painted behind him, adds a contrast as well 
as a sense of compassion for this moment of liminality.
info.Detailed Description:
In Abanindranth's pictures we see, for instance his adherence to 
the creation of Rasa (mood, flavor, taste) as being one of the 
ultimate aim of art. His use of analogy and suggestion to evoke

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A study of a peacock painted with a sesnsitivity towards the 
colours of the day rather than the animal itself. Coloured 
entirely in sepia, the peacock, posing outdoors has an earthy 
quality to it.
info.Detailed Description:
Leader of the Revivalist Movement in the field of Modern 
Indian Painting in Bengal, Abanindranath Tagore is also 
credited with a key contribution towards ushering in the

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Rabindranath Tagore's artistic adventure began with doodles that turned crossed-out words and lines into images that assumed expressive and sometimes grotesque forms. Many of them represent animals, but they are seldom of the real ones we know; more often they represent what he has described as a probable animal that had unaccountably missed its chance of existence' or 'a bird that only can soar in our dreams'. While Rabindranath Tagore did not acquire technical skills before he began to paint, the resemblance to the state of mind of a child is far more obvious. If this comparison with the impulses of a child painter is significant, to any extent, the paintings of Rabindranath Tagore may be called sophisticated child art, much more accurately than similar work of the many advanced artists, who have surrendered themselves to the methods of child art. Although he was untrained as an artist and sometimes referred to his paintings as foundlings, painting also made Rabindranath more observant and sensitive to the visible world. Tagore began painting relatively late in his career when he was in his sixties. His painting style was very individual, characterized by simple bold forms and a rhythmic quality, that later served to inspire many modern Indian artists.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Human figures are depicted either as individuals with expressive 
gestures or in groups in theatrical settings. In portraits 
produced during the 1930s, he renders the human face in a way 
reminiscent of a mask or persona. Tagore himself seldom spoke 
about his paintings: 'People often ask me about the meaning of my 
pictures. I remain silent even as my pictures are.' 
Tagore is best known as a poet and in 1913 was the first non-
European writer to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. 
Tagore began painting relatively late in his career, when he was 
in his sixties.  His painting style was very individual, 
characterized by simple bold forms and a rhythmic quality, that 
later served to inspire many modern Indian artists
info.Detailed Description:
Rabindranath Tagore's artistic adventure began with doodles that 
turned crossed-out words and lines into images that assumed 
expressive and sometimes grotesque forms. Many of them represent 
animals, but they are seldom of the real ones we know; more often 
they represent what he has described as 'a probable animal that 
had unaccountably missed its chance of existence' or 'a bird that 
only can soar in our dreams'. While Rabindranath Tagore did not 
acquire technical skill before he began to paint, the resemblance 
to the state of mind of a child is far more obvious.  If this 
comparison with the impulses of a child painter be significant, 
to any extent, the paintings of Rabindranath Tagore may be called 
a sophisticated child art, much more accurately than similar work 
of the many advanced artists, who have surrendered themselves to 
the methods of child art.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Rabindranath Tagore's artistic adventure began with doodles that 
turned crossed-out words and lines into images that assumed 
expressive and sometimes grotesque forms. Many of them represent 
animals, but they are seldom of the real ones we know; more often 
they represent what he has described as 'a probable animal that 
had unaccountably missed its chance of existence' or 'a bird that 
only can soar in our dreams'. While Rabindranath Tagore did not 
acquire technical skill before he began to paint, the resemblance 
to the state of mind of a child is far more obvious. 
Human figures are depicted either as individuals with expressive 
gestures or in groups in theatrical settings. In portraits 
produced during the 1930s, he renders the human face in a way 
reminiscent of a mask or persona.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Tagore is best known as a poet and in 1913 was the first non-
European writer to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. 
Tagore began painting relatively late in his career, when he was 
in his sixties.  His painting style was very individual, 
characterized by simple bold forms and a rhythmic quality, that 
later served to inspire many modern Indian artists.

Human figures are depicted either as individuals with expressive 
gestures or in groups in theatrical settings. In portraits 
produced during the 1930s, he renders the human face in a way 
reminiscent of a mask or persona. Tagore himself seldom spoke 
about his paintings: 'People often ask me about the meaning of my 
pictures. I remain silent even as my pictures are.'

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting is of four trees on a hilly region with two bushes 
at the bottom of two trees.  The trees are painted using ink & 
charcoal on paper, brush strokes all around the trees seem to be 
very powerful.

Tagore is best known as a poet and in 1913 was the first non-
European writer to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. 
Tagore began painting relatively late in his career, when he was 
in his sixties.  His painting style was very individual, 
characterized by simple bold forms and a rhythmic quality, that 
later served to inspire many modern Indian artists.
Although he was untrained as an artist and sometimes referred to 
his paintings as foundlings, painting also made Rabindranath more 
observant and sensitive to the visible world. In his landscape 
paintings done at the evening of his life he more often shows 
nature bathed in the evening light; with radiant skies and forms 
coagulating into ominous silhouettes they invoke mystery and a 
foreboding silence.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
His paintings portrayed the prevailing conditions in villages and 
reflected the colours of life. Starting with tempera, he later 
switched over to oil colours. His innovative style which is an 
idiom of Telangana region, have also been compared to the works of 
Jamini Roy.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting that recreates a raag, depicts a man, saintly in nature 
gesticulating towards the ground. Around him are smaller figures in 
action, one holding a bow, constantly keeping the visual connect with 
the person in the centre. This tempera painting has an inscription 
mentioning the raag or musical composition along with a date of 1529.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
'Prince with Ladies' is a painting of a prince and three ladies 
framed indoors. The women can be seen occupied with the Prince; 
engaged in ornating him, feeding him etc. In the 
foreground is a fountain set within the auspices of a garden. To 
the left of the painting, set against an orange background is 
spectacular tree painted in full bloom. The stem of the tree is 
elegantly painted 
showing folds of the bark as well as a three-dimensionality. The 
colours used 
in this painting are rich, especially the blue floor occupied by 
the figures in the painting. 
Estimated to have originated around the late 16th century in 
Rajasthan, Rajput miniature painting developed as an off-shoot of 
the Mughal miniature painting tradition. A form that was used 
largely to illustrate manuscripts and texts, Rajput painting, in 
its essence, portrays a desire to depict human love. 
Love in the form of devotion, lust, courtship, passion, desire, 
or music can be witnessed through intricately detailed paintings 
that combine lyrical charm with a subtle narrative visual 
language.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The painting depicts five women standing in an outdoor garden 
space. The central figure, holds a a pair of 
bells in her right hand and a musical instrument in her left, 
while the other figures, two on either side, face her in rapt 
attention. The deer, that can be seen on either side of the 
women, appear domesticated, as they have ropes around their neck 
and are being fed from bundles of grass. The foreground and 
background are filled with plants that have bloomed, amidst an 
evenly green garden. The artist draws the viewers attention to 
the 'lady musician', by involving the others present around her 
to gaze towards her. The women and deer, who create a centrality 
to the main figure, have their heads, and gaze subtly tilted 
upwards creating an air of worship and reverie. 

Estimated to have originated around the late 16th century in 
Rajasthan, Rajput miniature painting developed as an off-shoot of 
the Mughal miniature painting tradition. A form that was used 
largely to illustrate manuscripts and texts, Rajput painting, in 
its essence, portrays a desire to depict human love. 
Love in the form of devotion, lust, courtship, passion, desire, 
or music can be witnessed through intricately detailed paintings 
that combine lyrical charm with a subtle narrative visual 
language.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting depicts a seated prince surrounded by 
women and men. One woman who appears to be serving the prince 
stands with her head bowed down, a tray of cups in her 
hands. Another lady who is located at the base of the prince's 
throne has her right hand on the chest of the prince. 
In the foreground are men serving and drinking wine in elegant
cutlery. The prince himself is portrayed larger than all the 
other figures in the painting, emphasizing his status. At 
the bottom centre of this miniature is a water fountain gushing 
with water.  This could signify the overflow of 
intoxication and revelry depicted in this painting.

Estimated to have originated around the late 16th century in 
Rajasthan, Rajput miniature painting developed as an off-shoot of 
the Mughal miniature painting tradition. A form that was used 
largely to illustrate manuscripts and texts, Rajput painting, in 
its essence, portrays a desire to depict human love. 
Love in the form of devotion, lust, courtship, passion, desire, 
or music can be witnessed through intricately detailed paintings 
that combine lyrical charm with a subtle narrative visual 
language.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A four headed figure who appears to be Lord Brahma has been 
painted, seated within the walls of a building. A lady offering 
white flowers appears worshiping the god of creation -Brahma. 
Below her is an attendant figure holding a basket into which the 
offered flowers fall. We see foliage and a garden like setting in 
the background. The skyline depicts a red and yellow flag that 
rises from the finial of the building.
Estimated to have originated around the late 16th century in 
Rajasthan, Rajput miniature painting developed as an off-shoot of 
the Mughal miniature painting tradition. A form that was used 
largely to illustrate manuscripts and texts, Rajput painting, in 
its essence, portrays a desire to depict human love. 
Love in the form of devotion, lust, courtship, passion, desire, 
or music can be witnessed through intricately detailed paintings 
that combine lyrical charm with a subtle narrative visual 
language.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting depicts a scene taking place in the inner courtyard 
of a royal household. Located centrally is a lady of royal 
stature handing out, what appears like food. 
Opposite her are two female attendants with outstretched arms to 
receive the offering. Two women stand behind the princess : one 
holds a fly wisp, while the other watches the scene with folded 
arms. In the background we see trees and mountains in the 
horizon.

Estimated to have originated around the late 16th century in 
Rajasthan, Rajput miniature painting developed as an off-shoot of 
the Mughal miniature painting tradition. A form that was used 
largely to illustrate manuscripts and texts, Rajput painting, in 
its essence, portrays a desire to depict human love. 
Love in the form of devotion, lust, courtship, passion, desire, 
or music can be witnessed through intricately detailed paintings 
that combine lyrical charm with a subtle narrative visual 
language.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ramendranath Chakravorty, though the name may not necessarily 
ring a bell among the new generation, is still reverentially 
remembered by many senior printmakers and artists. He was one 
of the key players in establishing printmaking as an immensely 
innovative medium within the domain of modern Indian art. 
A quick look at his prints reveals his natural penchant for 
genre art, his ability to capture the locale with all its 
charms, and a deep engagement with the hitherto lesser-known 
mediums like woodcut, etching, linocut, etc. Ramendranath's 
art was informed by a dilemma typical of the period. On the 
one hand those times were marked by the revivalist environment 
with a strong swadesi bent, and on the other, in some of the 
individual artists at least, one could sense an increasing 
yearning for a wider exploration of the arts in both terms of 
style and technique.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This wood cut print on paper elegantly captures line, and succeeds in 
revealing an ethereal quality to the outlined face. From the 
iconography in the artwork such as the crown of thorns on the head of 
the figure, and well as an outstretched arm, this print appears to 
resemble the face of Christ during Crucifixion. However the artists 
has conveyed a more somber, peaceful Christ, which could mean it 
depicts the face of Christ after his passing away.
info.Detailed Description:
Born in Kolhapur, Maharashtra, Vinayak Masoji studied at the J. J. 
School of Art for three years. He was so attracted to the new Bengal 
School that he left home and came to Santiniketan in 1921. He joined 
Kala-Bhavana and studied painting under the guidance of Nandalal Bose 
and Asitkumar Haldar.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting titled singha vahini, or the rider of a lion, referencing 
the goddess from Hindu mythology, Durga who has been known to be 
painted riding a roaring lion. The visual language of this painting 
though has a strong influence of a Tibetan painting tradition, which 
found more popularity in the Northern hill areas of India.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The work depicts landscapes with a major portion of the 
composition dedicated to the sky.  Gaganendranath Tagore's 
landscapes are exceptionally emotive, in that they create a 
feeling of what the artist attempts to express. His earliest 
sketches and landscapes date back to 1905. Inspired by Japanese 
artist Yokoyama Taikan, Gaganendranath's landscapes achieve the 
right blend of capturing Bengal's vast landscapes and 
romanticizing them. Gaganendranath's  interest in life and later 
art, was limited to and conditioned by his love for everything 
swadeshi (native).

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting depicts four figures listening to a male figure, 
possibly telling a story.  The figures are situated on a hilly 
road 
side.  In the background we can see the mountain peaks.  The 
painting shows a strong influence of the Japanese wash technique.

Gaganendranath Tagore's landscapes are exceptionally emotive, in 
that they create a feeling of what the artist attempts to 
express. His earliest sketches and landscapes date back to 1905. 
Inspired by Japanese artist Yokoyama Taikan, Gaganendranath's 
landscapes achieve the right blend of capturing Bengal's vast 
landscapes and romanticizing them.
Gaganendranath's  interest in life and later art, was limited to 
and conditioned by his love for everything swadeshi (native).

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The practice of printmaking as a fine art medium gained immense 
popularity with the establishment of Kala Bhavan founded by 
Rabindranath Tagore in 1919, wherein new styles of printmaking 
were explored through an organization called the 'Bichitra Club'. 
A prominent member of this club was artist Mukul Chandra Dey, who 
was the first Indian artist to go abroad in the 1920's to learn 
graphic art.
Indian painter-engraver Mukul Chandra Dey, was an important 
personality of his time. A student of Santiniketan School during 
the early years of the 20th century, he left his mark as a 
pioneer of dry point-etching in India. Having interacted closely 
with such Japanese masters as Yokoyama Taikan, Shimomura Kanzan, 
his skill with lines, and familiarity and exposure with Eastern 
printmaking traditions such as the Ukiyo-e prints, widened. 
Dey used the copper plate, and print surfaces like a sketch book, 
which he would re work at a later stage and make prints of. Some 
of the thematics that recur in his work are rural landscapes, 
mythical narratives, festivals, and the indigenous people of 
Bengals; the Santhals. His prints of people often capture the 
graceful movement of limbs, and have been referred to as rather 
idyllic and romantic. His landscapes though are exquisitely 
portrayed spaces, always maintaining an ambivalence between man 
and nature, real and mythical.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A sketch of Rajiv Gandhi, as a small boy, by the artist reveals a 
close connection with the political circles. A student of 
Santiniketan School during the early years of the 20th century, 
he left his mark as a pioneer of dry point-etching in India.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A pencil sketch of a young Indira Gandhi, bold, confident, and 
very aware of herself. The artist's closeness to the Gandhi 
family, can be seen here, where he has sketched them from life.  
A student of Santiniketan School during the early years of the 
20th century, he left his mark as a pioneer of dry point-etching 
in India. Having interacted closely with such Japanese masters as 
Yokoyama Taikan, Shimomura Kanzan, his skill with lines, and 
familiarity and exposure with Eastern printmaking traditions such

of the thematics that recur in his work are rural landscapes,

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: The Daniell's were among the first wave of British artists working in India and the views they brought back to Britain were novel and exciting. This painting is one of the many watercolor paintings done in black and white. The artist has shown light and shade, depth, perspective, and even time of day, purely through shades of grey. The painting depicts an observatory similar to the science laboratory of Jantar Mantar in New Delhi. The building, a Sun Dial is located at the center of the painting. Three figures are shown watching the sundial while one of them points to the forming shadow. The figure in the middle holds a parasol for the two other men.
info.Detailed Description:
Indian landscapes by the Daniells remind one of Italian and 
British paintings of Roman or Pompeian ruins. There is a 
glorification or sentimentalizing of the past. The landscape in 
perspective includes oriental buildings interspersed with soft 
trees and a few small figures appropriately costumed. His palette 
shows that love of somber hues; browns, greys, and greens 
characteristic of English water colours, the pictures often have 
a low horizon and vast sky reminding one of Dutch landscape.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Originally from the Chittagong district of undivided Bengal, 
Sudhir Ranjan Khastgir studied fine arts under Nandalal Bose in 
Kala Bhavana, Santiniketan. He was known for an "Indian style" of 
painting, which began by depicting the beauty of landscapes, 
idealizing toilers of the land, and later creating abstracting 
themes from the mythical and historical past.  He was influenced 
by the Tagore family during his student years at Kala Bhavan, 
Shantiniketan, in its earliest stage. 

Khastigir, later went on to teach at Doon School, Dehra Doon for 
a long period as an art teacher, followed by becoming the 
Principal at Govt. Art College, Lucknow. His visual thematic 
broadly depicted, cheerful dancers, santhals, the Palash flower, 
amaltash trees and the like. Khastgir was also sculptor, and did 
portraits of several eminent Indian and British personalities, 
including Rabindranath Tagore and Jawaharlal Nehru. His 
sculptural compositions include themes from the real as well as 
the mythical world.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting of three women in conversation, this image reveals the 
bright colours of a rural scene. The three women appear to be 
conversing with one of them raising her arm, gesticulating in her 
conversation. She holds in her hand an earthen pot, and is perhaps on 
her way to fill water, a practice that is synonymous with rural 
India. the most noticeable quality of this painting is the decorative 
element of the women's saris, expressed in their bright colours and 
simple geometric patterning.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Here we see Jamini Roy's passion for the outdoor.  The landscape 
sketches show his keen eye for observing elements of composition, 
depth, perspective, light and shade and thematic.  Roy's use of 
the Bengali pat in an effort to restore art as a collective 
activity nourished by a deeply symbolic religious mythology has 
very interesting parallels with Oskar Schlemmer's. The German 
expressionist who like Roy wished to create an art of collective 
identity said, "non-natural treatment of the human form was 
superior because of it's symbolic nature, as seen in ancient 
culture, Egyptian, Greek, and Indian, nourished by religious 
faith." 
There was a phase in which he adopted the calligraphic brush 
lines of Kalighat Patuas to create sophisticated forms.  Roy 
brought the sensibilities of a formerly educated artist to his 
appropriation of folk form. His interest in depicting an earthy 
colour scheme can be witnessed in these landscapes where he 
restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow ochre, cadmium, 
green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In the 1930's Benode Behari worked as a curator for the Nepal 
government museum, and as an advisor to the Educational 
Department in Nepal, besides training artists in Mussourie and 
Patna. His encounter with a lama, such as the one in this 
painting, could very likely have been during this phase of his 
artistic career. Mukherjee led art beyond the dominance of 
literary subjects and mythology, to a form that gave importance 
to pictorial elements such as color, line and texture.
info.Detailed Description:
As an artist, he was one among the leading art figures of pre-
Independent India, who saw in Pan-Asianism an invitation to 
explore the linguistic rationale of different traditions. But in 
his study of Asian art he was guided more by his temperament than 
by the interests of his elders. This led him to focus on Far 
Eastern art and especially on its calligraphic traditions. He 
played a crucial role in the evolution of visual art as he broke 
away from the `Bengal Revivalist School`, and established a more 
modern school of art. Benode Behari recorded his visual 
experiences on small cards, and occasionally in large brush-and-
ink drawings or paintings. But owing to is weak eyesight that 
required him to study things from close to grasp the details and 
unravel the structure, synthesizing them mentally became an 
integral part of the process of representation.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Benode Behari Mukherjee led art beyond the dominance of literary subjects and mythology, to a form that gave importance to pictorial elements such as color, line, and texture. As an artist, he has experimented with many mediums, ranging from murals to collage, from woodcuts to calligraphy, from watercolors, oil paint, ink, and crayons to graphics. In this painting, we see three male figures amidst a domestic location. The central figure has a bow in his hands while the two other figures are situated behind him. In the background, we see houses, reflective of a domestic location. From the body language of the three figures in question, we see a playful attitude among them. The broad brush strokes used to reveal the artist's failing eyesight. The choice of his subjects shows his affinity towards rural life.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Two women are seen seated as if washing clothes. The attempt of 
the artist is to capture movement and character of the women. 
Benode Behari Mukherjee led art beyond the dominance of literary 
subjects and mythology, to a form that gave importance to 
pictorial elements such as color, line and texture. As an artist, 
he has experimented with many mediums, ranging from murals to 
collage, from woodcuts to calligraphy, from watercolors, oil 
paint, ink and crayons to graphics. He was known to record his 
visual experiences on small cards, and occasionally in large 
brush-and-ink drawings, or paintings. He explored the capacity to 
show character in a subject through the juxtaposing of positive 
and negative space.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: A strong influence of the Ajanta mural technique is evident in these paintings. The colors and objects in the painting stand out as isolated themes, and if removed and made to stand independent can still retain a serene quality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ganjifa , in its several forms of spelling, is a word signifying 
playing cards or card games in Indian and Nepal, Iran, some Arab 
countries and Turkey. The game of eight-suited ganjifa was 
popular in Persia under Shah Abbas-I (1587-1628), but the popular 
poker-like game appears to have been extensively developed in 
India in the late 18th century. The classic Mughal ganjifa with 
ninety-six cards and the standard eight-suits spread all over 
India, but apparently never reached the deep south of Tamil Nadu 
and Kerala. The Hinduization of ganjifa themes must have 
contributed greatly to the spread and popularity of the game. 
Dashavatara ganjifa with the incarnations of Vishnu presiding 
over the ten suits, was the popular card game in Rajasthan, 
Bengal, Nepal, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, 
Maharashtra and Karnataka.
info.Detailed Description:
The traditional ganjifa cards were handmade and hand-painted, 
each single card being a work of art, modest or ambitious, but 
always a work of art. The cards were usually circular in shape 
and their backs painted in plain colours. Occasionally the backs 
were painted with a rim line or a small central flower. Fully 
ornamented backs were only found in expensive cards and these had 
no tell-tale irregularities. The rich or darbar cards were made 
of ivory, tortoise-shell, mother-of-pearl and even inlaid or 
enameled precious metals. The bazaar cards were made of paper, 
fabric, papier-mch, leather, fish scales and stylo-graphed palm 
leaf. 
The structure and rules of play of both the games are essentially 
the same. However, the structure of the dashavatara ganjifa is 
modified in two ways. Firstly, the number of suits and cards have 
been increased to make the game more complex; and, secondly, 
figures and suit signs familiar to Hindu players have been 
introduced. The pack has ten suits, each of which represents one 
of the incarnations of Vishnu. In accordance with usual tendency 
to proliferate, the Orissan pack has expanded to twelve suits by 
the addition of a Ganesha and a Skanda suit, and has to sixteen 
and twenty suits by the addition of further divinities. With the 
coming of the European colonialists, the Portuguese in the 
sixteenth century and later the English and the French, the 
ganjifa gradually fell into disuse.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting reveals a painting technique enriched in a modern 
visual language. Almost fauvist in style, the painting uses the 
colour blue similar to the way the early fauvist of Europe used red. 
An artist familiar and trained in painting in various schools of 
painting, familiar even with Western art history, this painting 
attempts to understand both space and form while the artist succeeds 
in inventing a new style of oil painting.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A strong influence of the Ajanta mural technique is evident in 
these paintings. A continuous narrative within the same painting, 
where monk-like figures can be seen blessing and carrying a pink 
cloth. The trees and vegetation play the role of dividing the 
space within the painting, in order to enable a continuous 
narration of the story. In mussorie however, the picture plain is 
far less busy, with a more serene ambiance. A peaceful landscape,

be seen. The colours and objects in the painting stand out as 
isolated themes, and if removed and made to stand independent can 
still retain a serene quality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like 
pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him. 
While not an expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made 
sketching a regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in 
his art. Nandalal's exploration of the sensory uniqueness of the 
world around him is even more visible in his drawings. Running 
into thousands they show us men at work and rest, bringing into 
focus their body gestures, their looks, their drapes and 
ornaments, the form and structure of the objects they craft or 
use. His animal sketches with pen and ink, show his desire in 
rapid sketching on anything and everything around him.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The image of a well clad, adorned, Mumtaz can be seen seated in a 
very regal manner. In her hands that have been subtly depicted 
through the silk of her clothes, we see a Hookah, that she rests on 
her knee.
info.Detailed Description:
Abanindranath's inner urge for liberating Indian art was further 
inspired by Okakura, a great Japanese artist and art-critic who 
came to India with Swami Vivekananda. His work has a great 
delicacy of feeling, unity of concept, a highly sensitive range 
of color, tone, texture and poetic depth. His work was a mixture 
of traditionalism and innovation. He aimed at comparing nature in 
its transient forms and produce an image part object, part 
sensuous, both transposed into each other.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Haren Das was born in a small town called Dinajpur in, what is 
today Bangladesh, but was trained in Graphic arts in Kolkata. He 
worked as a teacher, and introduced line engraving and etching 
into the art curriculum of the Government College of Arts and 
Crafts, thus laying the foundation for print making and graphic 
art education in India.  Most of his works, especially his 
woodcuts and engravings, captured rural, pastoral Bengal, or 
laborers and the farming community at work. Despite using 
restrain and economy, Das has managed to offer a glimpse of a 
Bengal that no longer exists. Most of his work is a nostalgic 
reflection into a childhood and a youth spent at Dinajpur. In his 
works, the artist depicts man as part of nature, an individual 
who lives in harmony with the elements surrounding him.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sarada Ukil was born in Bikrampur in 1888 in district of Dacca in 
East Bengal, now bangle Desh. Initiator of the Delhi chapter of 
the Bengal school, Ukil explored Indian epics, history and 
mythology as subjects for his painting. The Bengal School effect 
vividly comes through in his pale and sentimental colour washes. 
Poetic and alluring in soft, moody palettes with fading outlines, 
Ukil excelled in portraying the drooping, love-sick maiden, Radha 
Krishna courting, as well as tableaux from literary classics.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Born in 1897 at Calcutta, Bireswar Sen grew up in stirring times, encountering the influence of western art and the revivalist movement, head-on. Sen was primarily a landscape artist, who worked largely in watercolor and pastels. One common thematic that recurred in his work was the Himalayan mountains, which he took as his leitmotif. Considered today as one of the orientalist heavyweights, Sen's landscapes rendered with a strong Roerich aesthetic form a counterpoint to the landscapes of the Daniells that saw in India's expanses an idyllic civilization, with exotic ruined buildings, typical of an Anglo-Roman visual language. In December 1942, Roerich said of him: "India should be proud in having such talented artists and cultured workers as Bireswar Sen."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Medium: Water Colour & Tempera Painting on Paper
