In December, 1942, Roerich said of him: "India should be proud in 
having such talented artists and cultured workers as Bireswar 
Sen."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Hari krishan Lall was one of the distinguished Punjabi painters 
who painted life and landscape for almost half a century. In all 
his artistic endeavors, he had one objective that is to produce 
paintings in as painterly a manner as possible. There is a 
distinct fragrance of Indian miniature painting in his work. His 
simple and spontaneous style has an immediate appeal which marks 
him out as one of the best colourists on Indian art scene.
'Colour was Hari krishan's passion and he transmitted its sensory 
effects on canvas with all his creative and imaginative power. 
His landscapes interspersed with human figures; animals and birds 
have a unique freshness and charm.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Roy Choudhury's sculptures consist largely of portraits and 
individual female figures, the latter of which became the dominant 
subject for his work. Perhaps his greatest contribution to modern 
sculptural practice in India can be attributed to his modeling 
techniques as well as the small scale at which his sculptures were 
conceived and realized.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: P. Perumal born in 1935, Virudhunagar District Tamilnadu, P.Perumal graduated with a First Class in Fine Arts(Advanced Painting) from the Govt College of Arts and Crafts, Chennai in 1957. He joined as an Art Instructor at the Govt High school in Kodambakkam in 1959 and continued to work as an instructor in several colleges and institutions for many more years. In 1988, he received a Senior Fellowship from the Department of Culture, Govt of India for two years. His childhood memories of rural life - the landscape, multifaceted Indian village, divinity, fairs, festivals, folk songs, dances, rituals, ceremonies, exciting rural sports - "All these have served as oxygen to my art". The plain and pensive paintings evoke our sympathy and concern for the underprivileged on the fringe of society. Full of linear motifs, the figures are lean and lanky with sloping shoulders and elongated limbs. The colors are dark, somber, and mute in keeping with the themes.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Although he was an active participant of the agenda of nativism 
espoused in early 1960s, within the Madras School of Arts and 
Crafts by K.C.S. Panicker, S. Dhanapal and others, his engagement 
with creating visual language premised on regional art forms was 
for a limited time span until the late 1960s; after which he 
contemplated a rethink on a return to academic realism.
His style of academic realism enduringly reflected his working 
methodology. He justified his arbitration with realism, claiming 
that the academic style of painting required mastering of the 
fundamental skills in drawing, technique and manipulation of 
colours in painting.  A student of both D.P. Roy Chowdhary and 
K.C.S. Panicker, he was particularly influenced by the former 
whose perceptual empiricist approach found expression in his 
painting and drawings.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting that reflects a Southern miniature school tradition, this 
painting resembles a period of Bhakthi art, where spiritual leaders 
were being portrayed a the path to attaining moksha. 
This painting done with tempera on paper, shows the saint Ramanuja, 
seated with the figure of an idol on his lap.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Three fisher-women painted in side profile, this painting elegantly uses the folk painting traditions such as the outward protruding eye, the simplistic figurative drawings, the flat application of the color, and so on. The painting shows an affinity towards both the folk technique as well as the rural landscape in depicting the fisher folk. It is interesting to note how the women's eyes, the decorative patterns of the landscape, and the fish in the seascape blend in to form a larger statement on the overall image.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Dhanapal was an influential painter and sculptor in post- Independence India. His sculptures, in particular, served as a visual bridge between traditional Eastern and the modern, ever-changing Western aesthetic sensibilities. Dhanpal used to paint with watercolors and tempera in the Bengal School style, but he had also adopted the southern idiom like the Lepakshi murals. He used to draw directly with a thin brush with simple, flowing lines and forms, creating compositions, revealing his powerful draftsmanship. Between 1955 and 1962, he made some remarkable sculptures like ``Mother and Child'', which were full of bhava. Without too many details they brought out the contemporary sensibilities of those days. The compositions were tight and compact

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Gaganendranath Tagore's landscapes are exceptionally emotive, in 
that they create a feeling of what the artist attempts to 
express. His earliest sketches and landscapes date back to 1905. 
Inspired by Japanese artist Yokoyama Taikan, Gaganendranath's 
landscapes achieve the right blend of capturing Bengal's vast 
landscapes and romanticizing them. Gaganendranath's  interest in 
life and later art, was limited to and conditioned by his love 
for everything swadeshi (native). 
in this painting, we are shown a cluster of Puri temples, 
emphasizing the architectural shapes, and pointed shikaras of the 
temples, rather than the details of the structures or the 
devotees around it.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Pochkhanawala's body of work, ranging from intricate preparatory drawings and theatrical sets to monumental public sculptures, explores and applies various materials, textures and techniques innovatively to engage with the concepts of time, space and nature, in a "rare marriage between form and content", as Anahite Contractor notes. "Since Pochkhanawala first began to sculpt in 1951 at the relatively late age of twenty-eight, her obsession was to unscramble the tight boundaries of space which were available to her through the time she existed in. Her arrangement of motifs, the strategic use of negative space around them, the aesthetic disproportion, and occasionally, her violent distortions even within the abstract mode she chose to work with, render to Pochkhanawala's sculpture a keen dynamism even today."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
'Picture of a Lady' is a frontal portrait of a woman, whose 
eyes  seem to look beyond the viewer, her lips  parted as if 
caught in a moment of speech. Her dress has been elaborately 
painted by Pithawala, who has paid attention to detail in color, 
folds, light etc. The woman's features, clothes, and skin  tone 
resemble  a European  familiarity : possibly the wife or family 
of a colonial officer in 1911.
Manchershaw F. Pithawala was a trained academic realist Indian 
painter and was a student of John Griffiths at Sir J. J School of 
Art in Mumbai. Acclaimed as a portraitist his art work depicts 
his acute observation of Western naturalism, and realistic 
portrait making. His understanding of techniques such as; 
chiaroscuro, color gradation, opacity, and layering reflects a 
rigorous training under a formal art institution that based 
itself on a Western model of art making.
info.Detailed Description:
The Uprising of 1857 was a watershed in the history of India, 
making the end of the old order. Although the colonial regime did 
not embark upon a systematic transformation of Indian taste 
through Western art schools until the 1850's, the "high noon" of 
empire, British taste had begin to infiltrate Indian aristocratic 
patronage form as early as the end of the 18th century. The first 
sign of change was the loss of courtly patronage in India with 
the fall of the Indian powers in the late 18th century.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painter who defied classification, Sultan Ali refused to be 
dictated to by the established mores of painting. Rejecting the 
guidelines laid down by European art as too formal and cold, Ali 
turned to the ancient art of folk painting in India for his 
inspiration. Gods and Kings, snakes and bulls, birds and cats 
people his paintings and have come to be identified specifically 
with Ali. He journeyed to Bastar to study the nuances of tribal 
culture and this experience enabled him to fine tune his 
technique and develop a style that came to be known as his own. 
Although any particular form of folk art does not influence his 
works, Sultan Ali's canvases are deeply imbued by folk themes. 
Animals and humans jostle for space on his canvases, sometimes 
even ending up inextricably mixed together.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
His paintings portrayed the prevailing conditions in villages and 
reflected the colours of life. Starting with tempera, he later 
switched over to oil colours. His innovative style which is an 
idiom of Telangana region, have also been compared to the works of 
Jamini Roy.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: An alumnus of the Government College of Fine Arts, Chennai, Santhana Raj was an extraordinary artist who dealt with space or the distribution of light and colour like no one else. He adapted the line and mass from temple murals to his own style, Tamil literature, myths, and folktales. He also did a series on folk dances, all in his own stylized idiom. His early works were inspired by Pallava sculptures.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An artist who came from a family of artists, the Ukil brothers were 
well known to have begun their artistic journey in the revivalist art 
movement and later moved into their own language of art making. 
This painting depicts the side profile of a woman against the 
moonlight. The arch of the moon forms a halo around the face of the 
woman. Her expression appears timid, as she covers her face with a 
sheet which on closer examination turns out to be an extension of the 
sky. Painted in 1955, this painting comes as a significant stylistic 
feature of artists who were trying to also capture the larger image 
of a nation, just having gained freedom.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Prof. Pran Nath Mago an eminent artist, educationist, and art 
critic, was a Founder Member of the Delhi Silpi Chakra. He has 
had varied experience -as a Professor in Fine Art, College of 
Art, New Delhi; Advisor to the Govt. of Malta on setting up an 
Art and Crafts School; and Director, Design Development 
Centre, All India handicrafts Board, New Delhi. His works, 
exhibited in India and abroad since 1946, were critically 
acclaimed and are in prestigious national and private 
collections.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A series of miniature portraits, these paintings are skillfully 
painted, with exceptional attention to detail and features. 
Painted on ivory, these miniatures would perhaps have 
originally been a part of an ornament. A unique set of paintings, 
likely to be the works of a guild in the Deccani area, have a 
smooth finish, and although very small, succeeds in capturing the 
character of the people being portrayed.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A series of miniature portraits, these paintings are skillfully 
painted, with exceptional attention to detail and features.

originally been a part of an ornament. A unique set of paintings,

smooth finish, and although very small, succeeds in capturing the 
character of the people being portrayed.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A series of miniature portraits, these paintings are skillfully 
painted, with exceptional attention to detail and features. 
Painted on ivory, these miniatures would have perhaps have 
originally been a part of an ornament, of gifts given to visiting 
nobility. A unique set of paintings, likely to be the works of a 
guild in the Deccani area, have a smooth finish, and although 
very small, succeeds in capturing the character of the people 
being portrayed.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:

painted, with exceptional attention to detail and features.

character of the people being portrayed.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: The painting shows a woman leaning forward, folded arms on a marble stair-case parapet. The composition is made vertically, enhancing the standing figure of the woman as well in the architectural elements of the marble. In the background is a water body and maintains that form the skyline. The woman looks upwards at the sky. Behind flowers and petals from the flowers fallen on the stairs.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ganjifa , in its several forms of spelling, is a word signifying 
playing cards or card games in Indian and Nepal, Iran, some Arab 
countries and Turkey. The game of eight-suited ganjifa was 
popular in Persia under Shah Abbas-I (1587-1628), but the popular 
poker-like game appears to have been extensively developed in 
India in the late 18th century. The classic Mughal ganjifa with 
ninety-six cards and the standard eight-suits spread all over 
India, but apparently never reached the deep south of Tamil Nadu 
and Kerala. The Hinduization of ganjifa themes must have 
contributed greatly to the spread and popularity of the game. 
Dashavatara ganjifa with the incarnations of Vishnu presiding 
over the ten suits, was the popular card game in Rajasthan, 
Bengal, Nepal, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, 
Maharashtra and Karnataka.
info.Detailed Description:
The traditional ganjifa cards were handmade and hand-painted, 
each single card being a work of art, modest or ambitious, but 
always a work of art. The cards were usually circular in shape 
and their backs painted in plain colours. Occasionally the backs 
were painted with a rim line or a small central flower. Fully 
ornamented backs were only found in expensive cards and these had 
no tell-tale irregularities. The rich or darbar cards were made 
of ivory, tortoise-shell, mother-of-pearl and even inlaid or 
enameled precious metals. The bazaar cards were made of paper, 
fabric, papier-mch, leather, fish scales and stylo-graphed palm 
leaf. 
The structure and rules of play of both the games are essentially 
the same. However, the structure of the dashavatara ganjifa is 
modified in two ways. Firstly, the number of suits and cards have 
been increased to make the game more complex; and, secondly, 
figures and suit signs familiar to Hindu players have been 
introduced. The pack has ten suits, each of which represents one 
of the incarnations of Vishnu. In accordance with usual tendency 
to proliferate, the Orissan pack has expanded to twelve suits by 
the addition of a Ganesha and a Skanda suit, and has to sixteen 
and twenty suits by the addition of further divinities. With the 
coming of the European colonialists, the Portuguese in the 
sixteenth century and later the English and the French, the 
ganjifa gradually fell into disuse.

of the incarnations of Vishnu. In accordance with usual tendency 
to proliferate, the Orissan pack has expanded to twelve suits by 
the addition of a Ganesha and a Skanda suit, and has to sixteen 
and twenty suits by the addition of further divinities. With the 
coming of the European colonialists, the Portuguese in the 
sixteenth century and later the English and the French, the 
ganjifa gradually fell into disuse.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ganjifa , in its several forms of spelling, is a word signifying 
playing cards or card games in Indian and Nepal, Iran, some Arab 
countries and Turkey. The game of eight-suited ganjifa was 
popular in Persia under Shah Abbas-I (1587-1628), but the popular 
poker-like game appears to have been extensively developed in 
India in the late 18th century. The classic Mughal ganjifa with 
ninety-six cards and the standard eight-suits spread all over 
India, but apparently never reached the deep south of Tamil Nadu 
and Kerala. The Hinduization of ganjifa themes must have 
contributed greatly to the spread and popularity of the game. 
Dashavatara ganjifa with the incarnations of Vishnu presiding 
over the ten suits, was the popular card game in Rajasthan, 
Bengal, Nepal, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, 
Maharashtra and Karnataka.
info.Detailed Description:
The traditional ganjifa cards were handmade and hand-painted, 
each single card being a work of art, modest or ambitious, but 
always a work of art. The cards were usually circular in shape 
and their backs painted in plain colours. Occasionally the backs 
were painted with a rim line or a small central flower. Fully 
ornamented backs were only found in expensive cards and these had 
no tell-tale irregularities. The rich or darbar cards were made 
of ivory, tortoise-shell, mother-of-pearl and even inlaid or 
enameled precious metals. The bazaar cards were made of paper, 
fabric, papier-mch, leather, fish scales and stylo-graphed palm 
leaf. 
The structure and rules of play of both the games are essentially 
the same. However, the structure of the dashavatara ganjifa is 
modified in two ways. Firstly, the number of suits and cards have 
been increased to make the game more complex; and, secondly, 
figures and suit signs familiar to Hindu players have been 
introduced. The pack has ten suits, each of which represents one 
of the incarnations of Vishnu. In accordance with usual tendency 
to proliferate, the Orissan pack has expanded to twelve suits by 
the addition of a Ganesha and a Skanda suit, and has to sixteen 
and twenty suits by the addition of further divinities. With the 
coming of the European colonialists, the Portuguese in the 
sixteenth century and later the English and the French, the 
ganjifa gradually fell into disuse.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting by A.E.Harris exemplifies the tradition of Western 
Portraiture technique, introduced into India by the colonial 
regime in the early 1900's. The painting pays attention to 
aspects of portraiture like the representation of skin, lighting 
of the eyes, nose and chin and the numerous medals pinned on the 
Lord's coat. Along his waist is a large blue band that is also a 
mark of official status. 
Born at Edinburgh, Scotland, Thomas Gibson Carmichael was 
appointed Governor of Victoria in 1908 and Governor of Madras in 
1911. He served from 3 November 1911 to 30 March 1912, and was an 
avid patron of the arts during his time. He was a Trustee of the 
National Portrait Gallery from 1904 to 1908 and of the National 
Gallery from 1906 to 1926. Lord Carmichael died at 13 Portman 
Street, London, in January 1926, aged 66, and was buried at 
Skirling Biggar, Lanarkshire.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The Daniells were among the first wave of British artists working 
in India and the views they brought back to Britain were novel 
and exciting. A lithographic print, this art work by Thomas 
Daniell, depicts a 
view of the gate of a mosque and the street outside it. In the 
painting, the building is composed at a diagonal on the left of 
the street which cuts horizontally along the lower center of the 
picture. The accuracy of the architecture along with the mastery 
over perspective, light, shade and verisimilitude is worth 
noticing. In the foreground and along the street are civilians, a 
bullock cart and worshipers returning from the mosque, painted to 
show the ongoing everyday in India.daniell's landscapes were 
typically picturesque, romantically showing the disorder of 
nature overcoming man-made structures.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The Daniell's were among the first wave of British artist's 
working in India and the views they brought back to Britain were 
novel and exciting. A lithographic print this art work depicts a 
distant view of the city of Mathura on the banks of the river 
Jamuna. A building with four minarets and a large fortress is 
visible on the horizon. In the fore-ground are three men, dressed 
in white, seemingly in conversation.  They have in their hands, 
long sticks and shields suggesting their soldier status.  The 
fascination of India is evident in the way this landscape print 
has been romanticized, blending the artist's desire to capture 
the Indian 'country-side' with a 'white man's' requirement to 
document the 'Orient'.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A lithographic print,'View of the Fort of Trichopoly' depicts a 
scene from the everyday; bathing figures, in the foreground with 
the fort walls and the temple on the rocky mountain in the 
background. This juxtaposition of the people and their dwellings 
portrayed in the horizontal with the fort and temple shown in the 
vertical establish the aspect of hierarchy as well as an element 
of monumentalization.
info.Detailed Description:
The Daniell's were among the first wave of British artist's 
working in India and the views they brought back to Britain were 
novel and exciting. A lithographic print, this art work depicts a 
distant view of the city of Mathura on the banks of the river 
Jamuna. A building with four minarets and a large fortress is 
visible on the horizon. In the fore-ground are three men, dressed 
in white, seemingly in conversation.  They have in their hands, 
long sticks and shields suggesting their soldier status.  The 
fascination of India is evident in the way this landscape print 
has been romanticized, blending the artist's desire to capture 
the Indian 'country-side' with a straight forward requirement to 
document the 'Orient'.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Balkrishna Patel was born in Ahmedabad in 1925 and he studied 
painting under the tutelage of Ravishanker Rawal at Ahmedabad 
and Prof. N.S. Bendre at the aculty of fine Arts 
M.S.University, Baroda. The current body of Patels paintings 
is minimalist, almost as if less is more for the artist. 
Patel uses the line to its optimum, he uses it sparingly but the 
impact he creates by the negative space is powerful. Patel 
also uses color sparingly, only a hint of it, as not wanting 
to burden the paintings.
info.Detailed Description:
Horse and women or the figure of the woman seem occupy the 
artists current repertoire. Both have strong symbolic 
implications, the horse a symbol of power, strength has been 
used in the realm of art since time immemorial, every artist 
has at some time or the other painted it, but what sets 
Patel's rendition of the horse apart is that he seems to be 
cajoling the viewer into rethinking about the associated 
symbolism of the animal. By putting the two, horse and woman 
together he seems to be balancing the 2 life forces, the male 
and the female, the yin and the yang. Though his line of 
thought is more serene, both are at peace with themselves and 
not wrought with intentions.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sarangan's work reflects an abstraction that stems from morphed 
forms strung together within rural Indian motifs. While the image 
of the cow, or bull can be found in his work, it is the glass 
like surface that he creates that immediately captures the eye. 
His colouring varies in rich hues, reflecting an oeuvre that 
ranges from painting to other art forms. The symbology of 
Sarangan's art also resembles a pre-historic image making style, 
with shapeless forms, patterning created in space, like rock art 
that can be found in caves.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jagmohan Chopra has been referred to as 'an artist's artist', 
someone who has consistently been ahead of his time in his 
various artistic expressions. Best known as one of the country's 
pioneer print makers, he has been equally progressive in the art 
of photography. Right from the 1980s he has been making and 
exhibiting photographs of exquisite beauty and impact.

Jagmohan's extensive experience in the fields of painting and 
graphics has been of great benefit to his photographic artwork. 
Adopting colour photography from the very beginning, he has built 
on his thorough understanding of the power of colour, and colour 
compositions. Whether it is his almost surreal 'Cuban Theatre' 
series, or his touchingly realistic 'Scenes of everyday life' 
series, they all seem infused with an inner brilliance and 
painterly light.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sarangan's work reflects an abstraction that stems from morphed 
forms strung together within rural Indian motifs. While the image 
of the cow, or bull can be found in his work, it is the glass 
like surface that he creates that immediately captures the eye. 
His colouring varies in rich hues, reflecting a oeuvre that 
ranges from painting to other art forms. The symbology of 
Sarangan's art also resembles a pre-historic image making style, 
with shapeless forms, patterning created in space.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
"My works are about human beings, but I like to put them in 
their historical and social context."
Arup Das is a figurative painter and an acclaimed muralist. 
Human figures occupy the central position in his paintings. 
Das attempts to portray man as a social and historical being, 
placed within the framework of his cultural and natural 
environment. He is as comfortable painting with oils as he is 
with watercolors. He is at his productive and innovative best 
when he is working with a combination of media. He employs a 
wide variety of shades to depict his human figures.
"There is a mingling of pictures and a blurred effect in my 
work which facilitates interpretations of my creations," he 
says. A recurring theme in Das's paintings is the coming of 
the Messiah with its message of eternal hope and ultimate 
salvation for mankind. Das's canvases are a judicious blend of 
ideas that are timeless but told in a language that is 
pertinent to our times.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
He painted landscapes that gave full rein to his penchant for 
nature and its fanciful shapes and colours, with the ocean being 
an endless source of fascination. Several of his paintings are 
surrealistic and abstract in his depiction of the teeming life 
underwater.  Primarily interested in watercolours, Dasgupta 
nevertheless painted in other mediums as well. He had to give up 
oils, when he developed an allergy to turpentine and linseed oil. 
Thereafter, he took up acrylic. But his preferred medium always 
remained watercolour. 

Moving slowly, but surely, from realistic images to the 
completely abstract, Dasgupta used textural changes and sharp-
defined colour schemes, making his landscapes come alive with 
shifting shapes and barely visible forms.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The artist, Eric Bowen, was born in India but lived in Oslo 
for many years, where his peace series was completed and shown 
in 1985. Its content is based on concerns about a world 
conflagration emerging from the cold war between the United 
States and the Soviet Union, and its relevance is more 
powerful now than it was six years ago.

Mr. Bowen's work has been largely in the non-figurative field, 
but this series combines architectural elements on which the 
quotations are inscribed with swathed skeletal figures from 
the Holocaust and Hiroshima. Somber in color and apocalyptic 
in concept, it also contains elements of hope and tranquility.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Laxma Goud began his printmaking in Black and White, and moved to 
color only after two decades of his practice. His iconography is 
earthy, sensuous, erotic and demonic at the same time. His 
animals and humans copulated unrestrainedly and openly in the 
village landscape of tress. The delicate use of line and the 
concepts surrounding fantasy where animals and sexual genitals 
are depicted pierced with ornaments. Fascinated with erotic 
subjects from the beginning by the late 60's he evolved a 
distinct style in his etchings which portrayed a pan-natural 
sexuality seen in terms of impulsive, aggressive passions rather 
than those of fertility

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In the artist's work, reality mingles with the world of his 
dreams. Though realism surfaces in Burman's paintings, often in 
the form of past and present members of his own family in India 
and France, he constantly and assuredly returns to the dream 
world. On Burman's canvases, one finds mythical creatures that 
tell ancient tales of courtly romances, bringing alive an 
enchanting world of comely maidens, children astride elephants, 
flutists, fruit laden trees, exotic flowers, birds and beasts; a 
lost paradise, where all creatures dwell in harmony. Each work is 
captivating, luminescent and delicate. Engaging with grace and 
beauty, he creates a sense of tranquility in his art.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
"I am something of a loner, I'd rather immerse myself in a good book 
or collect my thoughts by talking long, solitary walks. This gives me 
a clarity of vision that is reflected in my paintings." 

Laxman Shreshtha's abstract works are both, sensuous and meditative 
in their shifts and balances of colour. One can observe a palpable 
movement from chaos to spiritual peace, in his work. Shreshtha's 
canvases are an intermingling of vivid browns, yellows, reds, oranges,  and blues. These capture and emote passions dramatically, whether 
these passions are brooding, fierce or cheerful.
info.Detailed Description:
His work is intricately related to the events in his life and the 
struggles he has had to face. His journey, from being a member of an 
aristocratic family in Nepal, to a struggling art student on the 
brink of starvation, made him embark on a spiritual quest, which has 
been reflected in his work He looked for answers to his early 
existentialist dilemmas in books on Western philosophy. Later he 
turned to the Upanishads and to Buddhism. His paintings are a 
reflection of these experiences. Though abstract, his paintings have 
a sense of intrigue in them, that leaves the observer, and Shreshtha 
himself, as he confesses, trying to understand the shades of meaning 
they present.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ramendranath Chakravorty, though the name may not necessarily 
ring a bell among the new generation, is still reverentially 
remembered by many senior printmakers and artists. He was one 
of the key players in establishing printmaking as an immensely 
innovative medium within the domain of modern Indian art.
info.Detailed Description:
A quick look at his prints reveals his natural penchant for 
genre art, his ability to capture the locale with all its 
charms, and a deep engagement with the hitherto lesser-known 
mediums like woodcut, etching, linocut, etc. Ramendranath's 
art was informed by a dilemma typical of the period. On the 
one hand those times were marked by the revivalist environment 
with a strong swadesi bent, and on the other, in some of the 
individual artists at least, one could sense an increasing 
yearning for a wider exploration of the arts in both terms of 
style and technique.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The school of Arts, Madras was another center that produced many 
celebrated artists,under the guidance of stalwarts; Devi Prasada 
Roy, Mokkapati Krishnamurti (1910-62), Pilaka Narasimha Murthy, 
Antyakula Paidi Raju (b.1919), K. Srinivasulu, Dhanapal, and Ram 
Gopal. Paidi Raju, one of the founding members of the group,  
mostly followed the traditional style in his work, being 
influenced by the Lepakshi mural tradition. Though he was 
initially absorbed in the folk idiom, his work later turned to 
modern trends.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: A little-known artist, hailing from Secundrabad, P.S. Chandrashekar was an introspective artist who was influenced by people and things that immediately surrounded him. The three artworks 'Temptation', 'Sex Vulture Style' and 'Litho', depict a common visual narrative. The first two works are drawings done with ink on paper and convey a strong sexual innuendo. While we see animals, a Monkey couple in the former and vultures in the latter, the utilization of private human sexual emotions and behavior create a feeling of bestiality. Chandrashekar questioned and problematical sexual emotions between couples, through animal forms. The lithograph print, however, depicts sexual eroticism and bestiality between a frog and a wild boar, revealing vulgarity through the animal world. Chandrashekar also painted themes surrounding a rural life, its customs, and attitudes, that brought him critical acclaim

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Manu Parekh's early work explored the relationships 
between man and nature, as according to him, this was an 
energetic link that had to be celebrated. The artist also 
points out that, since then, contradictions have formed the 
basis of his artistic practice, no matter the subject or genre 
of his works. 

Polemics have always intrigued Manu Parekh - the energy of the 
organic form and the inherent sexuality within these forms are 
intangible elements in his works. His paintings provoke 
viewers to take notice of the world around them through the 
emotion, pain and anguish expressed in the subjects of his 
paintings. His colors and forms exude a volatile energy that 
can barely be contained within the confines of his canvas, and 
become an extension of the artist's personality.
info.Detailed Description:
Born in 1939 in Gujarat, Manu Parekh completed a Diploma in 
Drawing and Painting from the Sir J.J. School of Art, Mumbai, 
in 1962. 
Vivid colours and prominent lines are an integral part of 
Parekh's work and each exudes the energy that he attempts to 
capture. Parekh admits to being very strongly influenced by 
his surroundings. His stay in the city of Calcutta, for 
instance, drew him towards Santiniketan and the old masters of 
Indian art, Ram Kinkar Baij and Rabindranath Tagore. His 
appreciation of their work, more at a perceptual level than 
stylistic one, urged him to delve deeper into the thoughts 
that inform his own oeuvre.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Krishen Khanna's art typically had the city as its central 
concern, depicting images of working class life in Delhi. His 
painting laid bare the travails of migrant labour and their 
marginalized status in the megapolis that they were helping 
build. He often engaged with the nameless figure or communities; 
the cycle riders, bandwallahs, and other figures of the labour 
class, whose ideas of rootlessness, and alienation translate onto 
canvas. 
Khanna has come to be seen as a genre painter, a narrator who 
weaves and spins images out of fragments of time. On the other 
end of the spectrum he is an artist who encapsulates the climatic 
episode of myth or poetry into the painted image. Through a lack 
of physical detail; the paintings aspire towards a quality of 
timelessness. Khanna's gestural impact on the canvas and 
masterful deployment of paint to evoke the human situation is 
unmatched.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Pandya worked in every conventional sculptural medium like stone, 
wood, metal etc. with unmatched dexterity and has exploited new 
material with equal competence. A sizable section of the enormous 
body of work that he has produced during his long career which spans 
through almost six decades is yet to be showcased publicly. He 
experimented with unconventional material. In mid seventies, he 
returned to wood but unlike his earlier wood sculptures which were 
carved from solid rosewood logs, he constructed his sculptures using 
planks, wooden sections, trellis, and lattice resembling the wooden 
balconies in medieval domestic architecture of Gujarat and installed 
carved wooden busts with crooked faces in them as if peeping out of 
the balconies like the mischievous couples seen behind the Kushana 
yakshis from Mathura. Pandya savors their inherent absurdity more 
than their meaningfulness. Through a curious fusion of cheeky, 
insolent skepticism and na

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: This painting by Jamini Roy is a diptych, with both sections painted in a similar stylistic technique. It depicts individual female figures in profile standing in postures of classical Indian dance. Painted in a distinctly folk art style, with protruding eyes, and stylized facial features, the paintings show Jamini Roy's borrowing from the Kalighat technique as well as his use of inexpensive material such as mineral pigments and earth colours. The aim of the artist is to re-invent the folk visual idiom within the ongoing imitation of Western art in pre-independent India.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Bhagat frequently experimented with new and unusual media in his 
work. The unique style he perfected over the years illustrates an 
amalgamation of national heritage and artistic traditions and 
western artistic ideals, reflected in his use of geometric shapes 
and colour. Of all the media the artist worked with, wood seemed to 
suit him and his sculptures the best, taking on and communicating 
the many subtle motifs that were significant to him. Bhagat's style 
and body of work has often been compared to those of Victor Vasarely 
and Paul Klee, whose idioms also involved minimalist geometry

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Patel has been influenced to a very large extent by the rural setting 
that he grew up in. Animals are particularly favourite subjects for his 
sculptures. Although he has since moved to the city, he harbours an 
ardent desire of moving back to the pristine influence of his native 
village and working on sculptures using local materials.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A little known artist, hailing from Secundrabad, P.S. 
Chandrashekar was introspective artist who was influenced by 
people and things that immediately surrounded him. The three 
artworks 'Temptation', 'Sex Vulture Style' and 'Litho', depict a 
common visual narrative. The first two works are drawings done 
with ink on paper, and convey a strong sexual innuendo. While we 
see animals, a Monkey couple in the former and vultures in the 
latter, the utilization of private human sexual emotions and 
behavior create a feeling of bestiality. Chadrashekar questioned 
and problematical sexual emotions between couples, through animal 
forms. The lithograph print however, depicts sexual eroticism and 
bestiality between a frog and a wild boar, revealing a vulgarity 
through the animal world.  Chandrashekar also painted themes 
surrounding a rural life, its customs and attitudes, that brought 
him critical acclaim.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A moment immortalized, this sculpture captures the act of a predator 
and its prey. The cat has just caught a bird, and that moment has 
been translated into a bronze sculpture. The artist has effectively 
depicted the animal movement, the moment of capture, as perhaps a 
metaphor of being caught off-guard or being destroyed helpless once 
caught by the powerful.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Pasricha's early works mostly consist of sketches done in 
sensitive black lines that communicate a scene, a story or 
sometimes just a moment. Primarily a landscapist, his preferred 
medium was water colour. He painted several landscapes in and 
around Delhi, but it was the Himalayan ranges that became his 
theme and muse for over 50 years, inspired by the works of 
Nicholas Roerich. 
Working from memory, he recreated his landscapes with different 
kinds of brushstrokes and arrangements of lines and dots. He 
balanced his water colours using various warm and cool tones to 
delineate individual objects. While his early works and sketches 
are distinctly academic in approach, the gradual flow of 
abstraction into his works is discernible. Besides water colour, 
he painted with gouache and the impulse towards abstraction comes 
through in his cubistically painted houses in several landscape 
works

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ambadas was born in Akola, India in 1922. He received his diploma 
from the J.J. School of Art, Mumbai in 1952. His works are 
influenced by the constant and innate movement in nature, which 
leads to a crescendo of optimal expression. He is pre-occupied 
with getting beyond the surface into a formless, abstract 
reality, where the artist's intentions play no part. 
His style of work involves familiar whorls and whirls of the 
broad brush, with textures created by its hairlines. The dynamic 
movement of form, light and colour come together to create the 
abstract creations of Ambadas.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ambadas was born in Akola, India in 1922. He received his diploma 
from the J.J. School of Art, Mumbai in 1952. His works are 
influenced by the constant and innate movement in nature, which 
leads to a crescendo of optimal expression. He is pre-occupied 
with getting beyond the surface into a formless, abstract 
reality, where the artist's intentions play no part. 
His style of work involves familiar whorls and whirls of the 
broad brush, with textures created by its hairlines. The dynamic 
movement of form, light and colour come together to create the 
abstract creations of Ambadas.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Mohammad's paintings show a simple approach Capturing poignant 
images of Kolkata and its people has been the forte of artist 
Isha Mohammad. "The early years of his artistic career were 
smeared with hindrances - a conservative family, the early demise 
of his father and philosophical dichotomies - all of which molded 
the mind of the creative genius to find out his gradual flowering 
against all odds," recalls Gupta in the book.
Some of the interesting works reproduced in the book date back to 
the 1950s and 60s; they reveal the artist's impressions of the 
city of Kolkata and its people. Mohammad's paintings in recent 
years show a relatively simple approach in portraiture; in these 
works one can perceive subtle comments on sexuality, terrorism 
and socio-political issues.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
These paintings and sketches shows the artist's attempt in 
selecting individual sections of a larger folk idiom in creating 
a modernist narrative. For 
example,by isolating the elephant, the artist has explored 
a minimalist stylistic technique within a folk idiom, thereby 
enabling a fusion with a larger modernist visual narrative. His 
interest in 
depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in these 
sketches where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow 
ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jamini Roy's early phase was decorative, to a large extent. There 
was a fair deal of colour and motifs, whereas his later paintings 
were turning minimalist. His pata lines are simple and bold. 
Derived from clay images initially, the lines were roundish and 
later moved into a more stylized order. The 
speed and confidence of his detailed sketches show his 
accomplishment of the figurative and pursuits therein of the 
conceptual. It is the juxtaposing of folk motifs, like the 
features of this elephant within the logic of a larger modernist 
paradigm that made Jamini Roy's work unique.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
These paintings and sketches shows the artist's attempt in 
selecting individual sections of a larger folk idiom.  For 
example,by isolating the elephant, the artist has explored 
multiple 
stylistic techniques thereby giving that individual section more 
prominence. These sketches form the preparatory drawings for a 
larger series of paintings. Jamini Roy's interest in 
depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in these 
landscapes where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow 
ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jamini Roy's sketches are a window into the process behind the 
artist's methodology. His simplicity and spontaneity is reflected 
through his work. When he was thirty he changed his conventional 
practice of art and started drawing on his own surfaces made of 
cloth, wood and lime-coated mats. 
A remarkable feature of his art can be witnessed in his line 
drawings.  The 
speed and confidence of his detailed sketches show his 
accomplishment of the figurative and pursuits therein of the 
conceptual.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Here we see Jamini Roy's passion for the outdoor.  The landscape 
sketches show his keen eye for observing element of composition, 
depth, light and shade and thematic.  Evidently influenced by 
Pointillist techniques and Impressionism, his landscapes 
shows a quest 
for capturing nature's rhythm through colour and expanse.  While 
the sketches are titled 'landscapes', they are themselves drawn 
in an almost stamp sized scale so as to focus on the very essence 
of the landscape rather than the whole picture.  His interest in 
depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in these 
landscapes where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow 
ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The art work 'Prize with Printed Strip' is a collage of sketches 
surrounding a centrally placed printed illustration. The 
figures in the strip resemble humans of a past civilization 
attired with their head gear and costume.  Two main figures 
appear to be 
dialoguing over an object placed in between them, possibly the 
'Prizes'. Jamini Roy builds a narrative around these printed 
strips creating his own angle to the story. He also reveals the 
methodology behind the creation of his narrative structures 
within the folk idiom. Jamini Roy's integration of a global art 
scenario is also worth noting.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Here we see Jamini Roy's passion for the outdoor.  The landscape 
sketches show his keen eye for observing elements of composition, 
depth, perspective, light and shade and thematic.  Evidently 
influenced by 
the Pointillists and Impressionists, his landscapes show a quest 
for capturing nature's rhythm through colour and expanse.  While 
the sketches are titled 'landscapes', they are themselves drawn 
in an almost stamp sized scale so as to focus on the very essence 
of the landscape rather than the whole picture.  His interest in 
depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in these 
landscapes where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow 
ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Here we see Jamini Roy's passion for the outdoor.  The landscape 
sketches show his keen eye for observing elements of composition, 
depth, light and shade and thematic.  Evidently influenced by 
western Pointillists and Impressionists his landscapes shows a 
quest for capturing nature's rhythm through colour and expanse.  
While the sketches are titled 'landscapes', they are themselves 
drawn in an almost stamp sized scale so as to focus on the very 
essence of the landscape rather than the whole picture.  His 
interest in depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in 
these landscapes where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, 
yellow ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Here we see Jamini Roy's passion for outdoor painting. The 
landscape sketches show his keen eye for observing elements 
of composition, depth, light and shade and thematic. Evidently 
influenced by Western art techniques; such as Pointillism and 
Impressionism, his landscapes show a quest for capturing 
nature's rhythm through colour and expanse. While the 
sketches are titled 'Landscapes', they are themselves drawn 
in an almost stamp-sized scale thereby focusing on the very 
essence of the landscape rather than a portrayal of multiple 
angles. His interest in depicting an earthy colour scheme can 
be witnessed in these landscape series where he restricts his 
palette to - Indian red, Yellow ochre, Cadmium green, 
Vermilion, Grey, Blue and White.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jamini Roy's sketches are a window into the process behind the 
artist's methodology. His simplicity and spontaneity is reflected 
through his work. When he was thirty he changed his conventional 
practice of art and started drawing on his own surfaces made of 
cloth, wood and lime-coated mats. 
The speed and confidence of his detailed sketches show his 
accomplishment of the figurative and pursuits therein of the 
conceptual. This sketch reveals the process by which Jamini Roy 
imbibes the folk idiom as a thematic, wherein he draws attention 
to the decorative, and pattern-like elements to convey his 
narrative.  He is thus able to create an almost textile-like 
quality to his compositions.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jamini Roy's passion for the outdoor is visible in his landscape 
sketches that reveal his keen eye for observing elements of 
composition, 
depth, light and shade and thematic.  Evidently influenced by 
the Pointillists and Impressionists, his landscapes show a quest 
for capturing nature's rhythm through colour and expanse.  While 
the sketches are titled 'landscapes', they are themselves drawn 
in an almost stamp sized scale so as to focus on the very essence 
of the landscape rather than the whole picture.  His interest in 
depicting an earthy colour scheme can be witnessed in these 
landscapes where he restricts his palette to - Indian red, yellow 
ochre, cadmium, green, vermilion, grey, blue and white.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting is an outline drawing of a seated female figure.  
Painted using a maroon pigment with a mixture of black Jamini Roy 
explores the simplistic line drawings of the Kalighat pictures.  
The attempt here is to capture the posture of a seated female 
figure through a reductionist technique, purely through line.  
The brush strokes are broad and fast, paying attention to form 
rather than realistic detail. The 
speed and 
confidence of his detailed sketches show his accomplishment of 
the figurative and pursuits therein of the conceptual.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Bhattacharjee drew inspiration for his work from his early dreary 
days, where vivid images of his struggling - the crumbling walls 
of buildings and the multitudes of people living there - wove a 
certain magic in his mind. His drawings form a fitting 
introduction to his paintings, revealing the predilection of the 
artist for forms: forms that are consist in terms of tone rather 
than line. Bhattacharjee's women are a strange mixture of 
spirituality and sensuality. Different moods of the painter are 
reflected in his different paintings. Some times flesh and blood 
figures turn shadowy. Where women in his canvas are an 
abstraction, men appear to live in their own world. He creates a 
wide variety of characters in all walks of life, but his 
preoccupation is with female beauty. His use of art techniques of 
post Renaissance European oil painting could be responsible for 
creating this illusion of reality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Ganesh Pyne is obsessed with death. He can't forget his first 
brush with death, in the summer of 1946, when communal riots had 
rocked Kolkata. His family was forced out of their crumbling 
mansion. As he roamed around the city, he stumbled upon a pile of 
dead bodies. Working mostly in tempera, his paintings are rich in 
imagery and symbolism. "My first painting was 'Winter's Morning' 
which showed me and my brother going to school," he recalls. In 
1963, he joined the Society for Contemporary Artists. During that 
period he made small drawings in pen and ink. Initially, Pyne 
painted watercolors and sketches of misty mornings and wayside 
temples, variously influenced as he was by Walt Disney and the 
art of Abanindranath Tagore. He counts Hals Rembrandt and Paul 
Klee as the other influences.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This sculpture finds a similarity to the visual language of modern 
Indian sculpture prevalent and prominent in this period of the 
artists time. While form was abstracted, the thematic is retained in 
the larger series of works. Balbir Katt, father to Latika Katt, also 
a renowned sculptor today uses the minimalist language in sculpture 
to convey a more fluid thematic.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: This painting is the portrayal of an animal, possibly a canine walking up to the top of a rocky ledge. Set in a jungle, the painting evocatively captures the glassy water in the foreground and the wooded forest in the background. The lighting is given to the rock surface as well as the glowing eyes of the animal lend this painting a feeling of eeriness.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Shah was a member of Group 1890, a short-lived artists' 
collective founded by J. Swaminathan. Shah's predilection for 
drawing was natural. Being an inexpensive, transformative and 
free form of expression, it appealed to him in his negotiations 
with form and space. If one looks at his early drawings closely, 
one discovers the skill behind the chaotic black lines. These 
works are never predictable, and deeply ironic in the manner in 
which they use a simple medium to interpret complex contemporary 
visual fields.

This figure is pared down to an essential or primal state, 
displaying the precedence of form over narrative, a 
characteristic common to several Indian schools of folk art. 
Experimenting with materiality and texture, this piece challenges 
formal notions of representation and reality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
It is in his Himalayan paintings that one most easily finds 
evidence of the loftiness of spirit and sense of mission that led 
Nicholas Roerich to attempt the tasks he set for himself. 
Roerich painted over seven thousand paintings of the Himalayan 
landscapes. In them can be seen the sense of drama, the urgency 
of a message to send or receive, a traveler to greet, a mission 
to perform, a path to travel. The towering mountains stand for 
the spiritual goals that humanity must set for itself. The 
pursuit of refinement and beauty was sacred for Roerich. 
In this painting, Roerich also shows us his admiration for these 
mountains that he painted often by monumentalizing the white 
peaked mountain as if rising out of the ocean of blue.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: This painting shows a couple walking through a vast grassy landscape. The woman who is bare-breasted carries a bundle on her head. The man holds an object in his right hand. Although painted as if to show movement, the couple appears to have paused suddenly to view the landscape and possibly the journey ahead of them. Dressed in clothes that are reflective of social status, the couple seems to be migrating or journeying with their belongings with them. The streak of orange-white light on the horizon seems to reflect the streak of hope left in this couple for their future. The expressiveness of Sailoz Mukherjee takes a conventional form, yet they convey the truth in a wholesome way. Though economical, the drawing is fluid, stressing the case of the eyes, the gestures of the hands, and the fingers. Partition and rootlessness played an important role in the thematic choice of the artist.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Raza's seminal work in the past three decades is aimed at pure 
plastic order and formal logic. Secondly it concerns the theme of 
nature. Both tenets have converged into a single point, the Bindu 
series. The Bindu, symbolizes the seed bearing the potential of 
all life. Raza, who had been one of the original members of the 
Progressive Artists Group, Mumbai originally painted 
impressionist landscapes in gouache. In Paris this underwent a 
series of developments into the realm of colour field painting 
and finally to his present geometrically aligned forms.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In most of his paintings and drawings, childhood memories of folk 
ritual arts from my village in northern Kerala surge to the surface 
and flow onto the canvas or paper. "As a sculptor, I've realized the 
scope and limitations of each of the media I've used clay, stone, 
concrete, glass fibre reinforced cement (GRC), bronze, iron and 
stone/granite. To me, jewelry enamel painting is twice born because 
it is both fused and re-solidified leading to eternal purity."
info.Detailed Description:
Born in Kerala, 1937.   A painter, sculptor, enamellist, photographer 
and a research scholar acquired Diploma in Fine Arts from Government 
College of Arts & Crafts, Madras in 1971. He has had numerous shows 
across India & abroad. He has been awarded with Academy Fellowship 
from the Kerala Lalitha Kala Academy, 2006; Nehru Fellowship, 
Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Fund, New Delhi, 1983-85; Senior 
Fellowship, Ministry of Education, Govt. of India, 1982-83; National 
Award for sculpture, Lalit Kala Akademi, New Delhi, 1981; State Award 
for sculpture, Lalitha Kala Academy, Karnataka 1981 etc.   He lives 
and works in Bangalore, India.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Bhattacharjee drew inspiration for his work from his early dreary 
days, where vivid images of his struggling - the crumbling walls 
of buildings and the multitudes of people living there - wove a 
certain magic in his mind. His drawings form a fitting 
introduction to his paintings, revealing the predilection of the 
artist for forms: forms that are consist in terms of tone rather 
than line. Bhattacharjee's women are a strange mixture of 
spirituality and sensuality. Different moods of the painter are 
reflected in his different paintings. Some times flesh and blood 
figures turn shadowy. Where women in his canvas are an 
abstraction, men appear to live in their own world. He creates a 
wide variety of characters in all walks of life, but his 
preoccupation is with female beauty. His use of art techniques of 
post Renaissance European oil painting could be responsible for 
creating this illusion of reality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting that attempts to abstract a landscape of boats by the 
river side. Bright colours is the first striking element of this 
painting, which has been painted keeping in mind the fore, middle 
and background spaces. A woman with a child is seated in a boat 
in the foreground, possible waiting to cross the river. The 
river, depicts a colourful reflection of the sky on water, with 
boats and buildings populating the background. At the centre of 
the painting is a seated cow, sheltered by a building that 
resembles a religious place. Bright reds, swirly lines of the 
boats and their oars, blend into the mountains in the background. 
In the distance the boats and the skyscape unify to produce a 
mass of colour and thick brushwork.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: This sculpture captures the urbanity of animals through scrap metal. Kunhiraman has used the scrap metal of automobiles to create a form of a horse that is an animal of beautiful motion. He has combined the two as a satirical remark on the growing tension between man and animal, urban life, and that of the rural.
info.Detailed Description:
Kanayi was born on 25th July 1937 at Kuttamath in Kasargod District 
of Kerala. After completing his schooling, he passed the SSLC 
examination in 1957. By then he had already found his vocation. He 
ran away from home when he was barely seventeen because the elders 
strongly disapproved of his creative pursuits. He felt stifled in the 
conservative atmosphere of the traditional joint family, where the 
primary role of the youth was to obey unquestioningly the 
instructions of the elders, predominantly the patriarch.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Titled untitled composition, this sculpture attempts to explore pure 
form through its structure. The process of abstraction in this art 
work appears similar to that of simplification. However a hint of 
religious iconicity has been implied in the form, whereby the 
composition perhaps takes root from a cultic source. On the surface 
of it, the form has combined rigid shapes and structures to elegantly 
express an inner sense of the undefined.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Widely known as the 'renaissance man' of the Indian art, P. Khemraj 
focused on creating 'lasting art'. He had given a new dimension to 
modern art with his colourful and often mind-boggling depiction of the 
female form that reflected sensuality and extravagant view of life at 
large in his artworks.
info.Detailed Description:
For any Indian artist living in Europe for any length of time during 
his or her youth, it is impossible to ignore the rich possibilities 
of artistic expression in stained glass. Khemraj was no exception. 
Especially noteworthy is his use of luminous colours ranging through 
ultra - marine, indigo, orange colours that are not commonly found in 
nature. While talking about his powerful lines cutting across the 
paper or canvas, on close view, one can find the lines to be delicate 
with minute fluid shadows found as if in droplets of water under a 
microscope.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Bhattacharjee drew inspiration for his work from his early dreary 
days, where vivid images of his struggling - the crumbling walls 
of buildings and the multitudes of people living there - wove a 
certain magic in his mind. His drawings form a fitting 
introduction to his paintings, revealing the predilection of the 
artist for forms: forms that are consist in terms of tone rather 
than line. Bhattacharjee's women are a strange mixture of 
spirituality and sensuality. Different moods of the painter are 
reflected in his different paintings. Some times flesh and blood 
figures turn shadowy. Where women in his canvas are an 
abstraction, men appear to live in their own world. He creates a 
wide variety of characters in all walks of life, but his 
preoccupation is with female beauty. His use of art techniques of 
post Renaissance European oil painting could be responsible for 
creating this illusion of reality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In their deep browns and grey-blacks, there is a tribal character 
to the paintings of Bhaskaran. In the way the faces and other 
elements are delineated, there is certain directness. A versatile 
artist, Bhaskaran has painted a voluminous body of work, that 
includes figurative and the abstract. His deliberately overlooks 
this tradition and finds inspiration in the staid, though 
symbolic, marriage photography displayed in most homes in India. 
Most well-known is Bhaskaran's signature work, the beloved 'cat' 
series. Starting as a sketch of a wandering cat in his studio, 
this interest soon developed into an obsession with the creature, 
the feline animal becoming synonymous with the artist himself as 
much as the late M.F. Hussain was with his wild horses.
"My paintings will remind you of the elaborate facial makeup done 
by some African tribes. They are placed in deep shadow with light 
from a distant source striking one side of the face. They are 
sensitive and appear rather contemplative," he says.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Vivan Sundaram, a contemporary artist of India deals in a lot of 
variety of media. This variety consists of installations, 
painting, sculpture, printmaking, video art, and photography. His 
works constitute of various narrative methods that cite his 
exceptional skill to deal with his ideas and their articulation. 
Sundaram is an artist who has been consistent in his pursuit of a 
politically honed art. During the early 1970s, he was actively 
involved with the student movement, and worked with activists.  
One of the interesting dimensions of his work is the excavation 
of the historical through the painting. Often the historical also 
manifests as the personal in a situation of asserting a Third 
World identity and a position of solidarity with the exploited 
and the working classes.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: This painting reveals a central male figure resembling Krishna, playing his flute, while the women who surround him sway in a rhythmic eloquence to his music. The style appropriates and mural tradition rather than rendering it in a mannerist visual language. Born of Dutch-Sinhalese parents in Sri Lanka in 1901, George Keyt made an impact on the Indian art world with an exhibition in Mumbai in 1947. The Group 43, of which Keyt was a member in Colombo had defied the pretty, sentimental Edwardian art that existed in Ceylon and had issued a manifesto stating their modernist intentions. The modulations of forms with the line, the flat planar surface, and the structural coordination evoked in the paintings of Picasso, was a strong influence. The sublime love of Radha Krishna was frequently depicted in his work in all its earthy, erotic splendor.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Prof. Vidya Bhushan's painting is a play with colour and fluid forms. 
While his abstraction is typically a morphing of the figurative, his 
use of contrasting colours makes for narrative through pure 
abstraction.
info.Detailed Description:
Prof. Vidya Bhushan, a freedom fighter and an artist worked 
with oils, egg-tempera, water colour, etchings murals in 
mosaic, and frescoes. He is one of the few artists, in India, 
to have made original copies of the Ajanta cave paintings and 
its widely recognized as being the only artist to do so using 
egg-tempera medium. Vidya Bhushan was deputized by the State 
Government to work in the caves as early as 1952, and was 
commissioned by the Archeological Department of Hyderabad to 
copy the Ajanta murals for their archives. He was also 
commissioned by the State Government to make portraits of 
Gandhi, Nehru, Sardar Patel, Abdul Kalam Azad, T.Prakasham, 
Indira Gandhi and Rajiv Gandhi.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A marble sculpture depicting abstract form. The artist appears to have 
used the form of the stone to express his idea. The intention of 
creating a bird, a being that symbolizes freedom and movement, in 
marble, symbolic of solidity and rootedness makes for an interesting 
thought process.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: A sculpture made in oxidized copper relief, and framed to appear like a painting, this sculpture of Ardha Ganeshwari brings an interesting juxtaposition of mediums and content. The figure combines the male and female within the body of Ganesh who himself is a half-human half elephant. The sculpture thus complicates form further by having the male, female, and animal forms within the same structure. The symbols portrayed follow the usual iconography of the god Ganesh, however, the artist depicts this figure seated on a lion. The medium of oxidized copper accentuates the unusuality of this figure and embellishes the fusion of forms.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sarada Ukil was born in Bikrampur in 1888 in district of Dacca in 
East Bengal, now bangle Desh. Initiator of the Delhi chapter of 
the Bengal school, Ukil explored Indian epics, history and 
mythology as subjects for his painting. The Bengal School effect 
vividly comes through in his pale and sentimental colour washes. 
Poetic and alluring in soft, moody palettes with fading outlines, 
Ukil excelled in portraying the drooping, love-sick maiden, Radha 
Krishna courting, as well as tableaux from literary classics.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This is the earlier work of B.B.Mukherjee  when he was in 
Santinikethan.  In this art work we see an etching of nature as 
the 
central theme.  As an artist, he was one among the leading art 
figures of pre-Independent India, who saw in Pan-Asianism an 
invitation to explore the linguistic rationale of different 
traditions. But in his study of Asian art he was guided more by 
his temperament than by the interests of his elders. This led him 
to focus on Far Eastern art and especially on its calligraphic 
traditions. He played a crucial role in the evolution of visual 
art as he broke away from the `Bengal Revivalist School`, and 
established a more modern school of art. Benodebehari recorded 
his visual experiences on small cards, and occasionally in large 
brush-and-ink drawings or paintings. But owing to is weak 
eyesight that required him to study things from close to grasp 
the details and unravel the structure, synthesizing them mentally 
became an integral part of the process of representation.
