info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: An abstract painting, this artwork places emphasis on the two prominent colours of red and green. The figures in the painting appear to be in conversation and create a sense of dynamic in the way they have been composed.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
True artists are committed to passion for their calling and will 
not be distracted by compromises deemed inevitable for a cozy and 
smooth living. The Rodin like ruggedness and energy in her 
colossal Nehru for Jawahar Bhavan, New Delhi and the work in 
progress Indira Gandhi is a testimony to her command over the 
medium and her technical prowess.
Banaras, the city of her adoption, is reflected in her work in 
forms and themes hardly ever attempted by any sculptor. In 
Latika's universe nothing is too insignificant for her keen eyes 
and dexterous hands.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Amarnath Sehgal's artworks served as a bridge between the people and the artist, who stood for artistic freedom, courage, and moral right of artists to their work. An individualist to the core Sehgal believed that one must be subservient to one's aim and ideals.
info.Detailed Description:
Born in 1922, he graduated in Industrial Chemistry from Benares in 
1941. He worked as an engineer and studied art privately at Lahore. 
He left for the United States in 1949 and earned a master's degree 
in art from the New York University. His works are exhibited across 
continents spanning North America, Africa, Europe, Australia, New 
Zealand and India.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Over the years Nandalal Bose experimented with a variety of 
styles, from robust figuration to a zen like abstraction, that 
captured the essence of his subject. In this art work, a strong 
influence of Eastern painting techniques where the 
delicacy 
of the material, texture, and colour quality that tempera evokes
evocatively, suited Bose's compositions. This painting shows a 
seated figure, his back to the viewer, looking into the landscape 
in front of him. Bose shows us his interest in the wash technique 
by giving a large expansive space to the landscape in this 
painting.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
It is in his Himalayan paintings that one most easily finds 
evidence of the loftiness of spirit and sense of mission that led 
Nicholas Roerich to attempt the tasks he set for himself. While 
at a visual level, 'Dwellings of the Thakurs' depicts a panoramic 
view of the mountainscape and the dwellings visible in the 
right hand corner, this painting like many of Roerich's 
landscapes, fuses the ethereal within nature through colour and 
context. The settlement is shown as mere white blocks amidst the 
diagonals of the mountains, suggestive of Roerich's desire to 
contrast the transitory with the eternal.
info.Detailed Description:
Roerich painted over seven thousand paintings of the Himalayan 
landscapes. In them can be seen a sense of drama, the urgency 
of a message to send or receive, a traveler to greet, a mission 
to perform, a path to travel. The towering mountains stand for 
the spiritual goals that humanity must set for itself. The 
pursuit of refinement and beauty was sacred for Roerich.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: "The days of paints and brushes are almost vanishing. With the evolution of technology, art is also getting a make-over. Every field is fast-changing, so why not art? We have to keep alive the traditional art, but we don't have to stick to it completely. Contemporary times are giving scope for change," said Yadagiri Rao. Aekka Yadagiri Rao started his artistic journey in the early 1960s. His inspiration was his uncle Raghava, who himself was a sculptor. Under his tutelage, Yadagiri Rao who was in his teens then started making Ganesh idols from plaster of Paris for Vinayaka Chavithi festivals
info.Detailed Description:
Born 1938, Hyderabad, AP. Sculptor and Painter. Graduated and Diploma 
in Fine Arts from Osmania University Hyderabad. Received 15 All India 
awards including two gold medals. Participated in state, national and 
international art exhibitions. Represented in SAARC meet -Bangalore 
1986. Honoured as eminent artist of state and a monograph on life and 
work was brought out in 1984. Represented in various institutional 
and individual collections in India and abroad. Presently teaching at 
Osmania University, Hyderabad.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Anupam Sud brings out the growing friction in a man-woman relationship where she shows them sitting close to one another but looking in different directions. Are these early signs of a crumbling personal relationship or the impossibility of dialogue? Her etchings are often satirical comments on the crumbling infrastructure of the ever-expanding city of Delhi, where the ambiguity and uncertainty of urban life spill over into human relationships, leading to a collapse of dialogue and connection. The dual experience of alienation and belonging is an urban phenomenon that creates multiple identities of the self, making life performance through a series of masquerades.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A well known artist and eminent sculptor of the state of Jammu, 
Khajuria is attempting to play with form in this marble sculpture. 
The curvature of the structure and well as the posturing, reveals an 
influence of the art nouveau movement. 
The artist appears to be abstracting with the form of anatomy and so 
figurative forms can be identified in a series of marble sculptures.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sailoz Mukherjee painted the Indian landscape in such an easy, 
un-intellectual, unpretentious directness that he seemed to have 
missed the experimental spirit of the times. Though economical, 
the drawing is fluid, stressing the mood of the landscape. The 
expressivity of Sailoz Mukherjee takes a conventional form, yet 
they convey the truth in a wholesome way. Partition and 
rootlessness played an important role in the thematic choice of 
the artist.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Painter, engraver and silk-screen printer, Panchal is a versatile 
artist , particularly inspired by monochromy and research on 
space. To begin with, he painted a series of oil paintings mixed 
with sand on canvas. He was always attracted to non-
representative art. "I liked the meditative aspect of art. Space 
formed the crux of my work. I always cared to create space". He 
painted a series of oil paintings mixed with sand on canvas, 
"Horses", exhibited at Gallery Chemould, Mumbai, in 1964. 
"Horses" were a pretext to compose and create space. "I enjoy 
working on my own, listening to Indian classical music, one of my 
favourite inspiration : actually the feeling of the music 
entirely agrees with my research of space and colour."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Sailoz Mukherjee painted the Indian landscape in such an easy, 
un-intellectual, unpretentious directness that he seemed to have 
missed the experimental spirit of the times. Though economical, 
the drawing is fluid, stressing the case of the eyes, the 
gestures of the hands and the fingers. The expressivity of Sailoz 
Mukherjee takes a conventional form, yet they convey the truth in 
a wholesome way. Partition and rootlessness played an important 
role in the thematic choice of the artist.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A versatile artist and a pioneer of the modern art movement in 
South India, Velu. Viswanathan, was born in Kollam, Kerala in 
the year 1940. He innovated with styles, sometimes mixing 
watercolors and oils, as a result of which the transparency of 
one medium blends into the opacity of the other. In his work done 
in the 1970s, he even used gold and silver colors. His early work 
was figurative. He later evolved to experiment with abstract and 
geometric forms. Inspired by geometrical ritualistic-magical 
diagrams of his native Kerala, he explored the visual language 
inherent in them with a gradual evolution of form and color.Velu Viswanathandraws with a particularly arresting technique. The 
outline is drawn with thick stamping ink, and then oil paint is 
applied with a brush and the work washed with turpentine.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A burning pine tree that stands tilted; grey smoke rises from its 
cracked-open bark and blurs the viewer's vision. The trunks of 
the other pine trees in the foreground rise into the patchy 
Columbian 
blue sky. Amidst this scene, located off centre, is a lone rider 
on horseback, making his way through the mountain road. In this 
painting 'Burning Pine', Nandalal Bose uses the Japanese 
technique of wash as well as perpectival play to emphasize his 
desire for dialogue between nature and humanity.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like 
pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him. 
While not an expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made 
sketching a regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in 
his art. Nandalal's exploration of the sensory uniqueness of the 
world around him is even more visible in his drawings. Running 
into thousands they show us men at work and rest, bringing into 
focus their body gestures, their looks, their drapes and 
ornaments, the form and structure of the objects they craft or 
use. His animal sketches with pen and ink, show his desire in 
rapid sketching on anything and everything around him.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting depicts a panoramic view of a landscape, painted 
with attention to the effect of the wash technique. The expanse 
of a mountain-scape is elegantly painted through black and white, 
water colour on paper.  While the mountains occupy the attention 
of the viewer, it is the elusive passage running through them 
that remains the focus of the artist. 'Hazaribagh Road' is a 
painting that reflects Nandalal Bose's pursuit towards 
juxtaposing nature and humanity.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Inscription:
Early into his artistic career, Nandalal Bose found inspiration 
in India's ancient mural tradition at Ajanta and Ellora. The 
impact of this influence is evident in this painting, wherein the 
eyes of the central figure are painted in the same half-closed 
manner with a lyrical quality. Many of the artists of the Bengal 
school found it important to imitate this stylistic language as 
an allegiance towards an ancient tradition.
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like 
pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him. 
While not an expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made 
sketching a regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in 
his art. Nandalal's exploration of the sensory uniqueness of the 
world around him is even more visible in his drawings.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Gandhi placed Nandalal Bose in-charge of creating a unique 
environment infused with local art and craft, for the annual 
session of the Indian National Congress at Haripura, near Bardoli 
in Gujarat in February of 1938. As a significant component of 
this huge public art campaign, Nandalal planned separate 
paintings which were later to become famous as 'Haripura posters' 
depicting Indian life in all its variety. The charm and the 
playful gaiety exuded by the linguistic 
features blend perfectly well with the contents depicting 
subjects like Hunters, Musicians, Bull Handlers, Carpenter, 
Smiths, Spinner, Husking women and modest scenes of rural life 
including animal rearing, child-nursing and cooking. The 
simplicity of these works also lies in the unvarying use of the 
point-cusped niche that frames the principal subject.

Haripura posters celebrate the Indian rural life and culture 
sharing a vibrant earthy color palette and bold, energetic lines 
with a vividly modernist graphic quality. A sweeping look at the 
available images reveals that these posters draw attention to the 
different activities, professions and trades that constellate the 
moments of village daily life in a picturesque continuum. Most of 
the imagery culled from his observed reality around were 
developed from the rapid sketches Nandalal did during his survey 
of rural areas and people living near the location. The vigorous 
dynamic forms of certain figures of course cut across the frame 
thus saving the images from monotony. Created on handmade papers 
stretched on straw-board, these paintings or posters were 
executed with brilliant colors prepared and mixed from the local 
earth pigments. For Gandhi, art and Nandalal were synonymous and 
he was proud and happy to have 'discovered' Nandalal as the 
artist of the Indian National Congress.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Over the years Nandalal Bose experimented with a variety of 
styles, from robust figuration to a zen like abstraction, that 
captured the essence of his subject. In this art work, a strong 
influence of Eastern painting techniques is visible, where silk 
was used as a base instead of canvas, wood or paper. The delicacy 
of the material, texture, and colour quality that silk had 
evocatively suited Bose's compositions..

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities, and the 
landscapes he saw around him. While not an 
expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made sketching a 
regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in his art. His 
animal sketches with pen and ink, show his desire in rapid 
sketching of anything and everything around him.

sketching on anything and everything around him. This sketch is a

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities, and the 
landscapes he saw around him. While not an 
expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made sketching a 
regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in his art. His 
animal sketches with pen and ink, show his desire in rapid 
sketching of everything around him. His sketches of trees, and 
scenic landscapes are mostly done in water colour, and were often 
later used as preparatory sketches for his tempera compositions. 
The artist's control over water colour technique and 
compositional quality can be witnessed in these art works.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
'Natir-Puja' is a series of six preparatory sketches made by 
Nandalal Bose, for what was to become, a series of wall murals, 
with the same title. Literally translated into 'The dancing 
girl's worship', these sketches combine the artists' skill of 
stylization with the realistic, to create fluid sketches that 
follow a story-board like format. The drawings themselves are 
rapidly drawn pen and ink lines on postcard, an habit Bose 
practiced regularly, for sketching, especially in public. The 
drawings show remarkable dexterity in composition and skill in 
capturing movement. In 1926, 'Natir Puja', was popularly known as 
the film directed by Rabindranath Tagore based on his stage 
dance-drama. The likeness of Bose's drawings to a stage dance-
drama are striking, however the film does not reveal a direct 
connection. 
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like 
pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him. 
While not an expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made 
sketching a regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in 
his art. Nandalal's exploration of the sensory uniqueness of the 
world around him is even more visible in his drawings. Running 
into thousands they show us men at work and rest, bringing into 
focus their body gestures, their looks, their drapes and 
ornaments, the form and structure of the objects they craft or 
use.

drawings show remarkable dexterity in composition and skill in 
capturing movement. In 1926, 'Natir Puja', was popularly known as 
the film directed by Rabindranath Tagore based on his stage 
dance-drama. The likeness of Bose's drawings to a stage dance-
drama are striking, however the film does not reveal a direct 
connection. 
Nandalal Bose, sketched animals, domestic activities like 
pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him. 
While not an expressly political artist, Nandalal Bose made 
sketching a regular part of his quest to reaching simplicity in 
his art. Nandalal's exploration of the sensory uniqueness of the 
world around him is even more visible in his drawings. Running 
into thousands they show us men at work and rest, bringing into 
focus their body gestures, their looks, their drapes and 
ornaments, the form and structure of the objects they craft or 
use.

info.Brief Description:

pooja's, festival worship and the landscapes he saw around him.

around him is even more visible in his drawings. Running into

narrative of an event, revealing the artist's methodology in 
making preparatory sketches for his larger compositions.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A student of K.C.S. Paniker and S. Dhanapal, Janakiram was an 
important member of the Madras Art Movement. Over the course of his 
career, the artist developed a distinctive idiom, in which he used 
beaten sheet metal decorated with repousse work to render two-
dimensional, frontal portrait sculptures. Influenced by the 
traditional temple sculptures of South India, particularly kavachas 
or doorway covers made from beaten metal, there are several 
religious icons amongst his body of works, ranging from Balaji to 
Christ.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: K.Khosa's artistic inquiry has impelled him to collaborate with his contemporaries in poetry, literature, and theatre. The first decade belonged to the genre where the subject of the painting was important. The colours and forms were only instrumental here. The second decade went on to reflect the storm of emotions or passions. Here the lines that were flowing were sinuous and yet tense. The third decade that is the present phase belongs to someone who looks outwards, even when he learns to turn his gaze inwards to become aware of a secret life that is, the larger life buried within. "The truly humane art is a wrestle with ourselves; it is to entangle the self with the basic stuff of reality; it is to get out of our time-bound egos and to enter the worlds of universal energy. Can there be any other purpose of art than to convey this energy''

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: His paintings are often about death and horror. He is a master of the horrific in art. Das's images of the bulls were inspired by his observations during a trip to Spain. Sunil Das emerged on the Indian art scene as a painter with an astonishing repertoire of technical and formal capabilities. In his subsequent works, whatever the subject, Das poured himself out on canvas in an obsessed mode of working. He never hesitated while experimenting with techniques, mediums, and styles, charging his images with new ideas.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Inspired by toys, acquaintances, and incidents from his childhood in India, each piece becomes specific and unique, its character subtly revealed through clothing, facial expression, posture, and use of hands. It is Jagdish's depiction of intimate human emotion that gives his works such universal appeal, affectionately commenting on society and dramatically narrating his stories. In 1991, Jagdish was the first Indian offered the status of "artist in residence" at Lakeside Studio outside of Chicago.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting appears to be depicting the play of light and texture 
within indoor and outdoor space. While the image itself is abstracted, 
the effect of falling sun-light seems to fill the room like atmosphere. 
The criss-crossing texture across the whole painting, gives a sense of  
patterning while evoking a textile quality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In his new canvases the viewer would find the play of colours - 
gold, silver, copper, bronze and pearl - in as varied a manner as 
possible. Like the shine of the sun and the moonlit change the 
day and night into a spectrum of different emotions and feelings 
thus evoking a special mood, colour and music to each one of 
them. "An organic feel of the silent activity of nature, 
intensive chirping of the birds in the low light of morning and 
evening, the transcendental music of light - all this and much 
more is an integral part of my creative quest. Light plays in my 
painting." And in this play the changing tones, textures, hues 
and shades create a Rgmala of its own. And in the shine and 
sparkle of the Rgmala, he not only experiences his childhood but 
also the realisation of his growth.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Hailing from the state of West Bengal, Dharamanarayan Dasgupta 
studied at Kala Bhavan, Shantiniketan. During the course of his 
search for a form that would adequately express his sentiments, 
he flirted with art styles that flourished as offshoots of 
traditional Indian art, mingled with Western ideals that were the 
trademark of the 19th century. His paintings also contained 
remnants of the 'babu' culture, a legacy from British India. Soon 
he cleverly blended all these cultures with his own inimitable 
style, and succeeded in achieving a distinctive look in his 
paintings.
Bizarre images crowd his canvasses and form an integral part of 
his art: images that float in the air, survey the world with 
their legs pointing skyward, distorted beyond recognition.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
From the gentleness and resignation in his earlier works, Amitava 
has now moved on to canvases that depict the violence and avarice 
of modern times. Working with a variety of mediums, Amitava uses 
watercolours, oils, and pastels to portray his thoughts and 
feelings evoked by his observations of the life around him.  all 
his canvases have a common, striking quality: the stress on 
background and the layers of colours laid on the surface through 
which the images emerge. "It is this paying attention to detail 
that helps me define the space in my paintings", he explains. 
Sympathetic and gently probing, Amitavas paintings are peopled by 
figures of men and women, animals, trees, birds, clouds, the sky, 
earth, sun, and even the wind. They are all about humans who 
maintain their dignity, even while suffering, bearing pain 
without a murmur and with patient resolution and who have an 
ability to bend before adversity without breaking.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Each of Arpita Singh's drawings, water colours on paper, and 
oils on canvas has a story to tell. The artist's colours are 
vibrant, her palette usually dominated by pinks and blues, and 
her paintings burst at the seams with teeming life forms and 
objects or motifs like guns, cars, planes, animals, trees and 
flowers. Described as a figurative artist and a modernist, 
Arpita Singh still makes it a point to stay tuned in to 
traditional Indian art forms and aesthetics, like miniaturist 
painting and different forms of folk art, employing them in 
her work regularly. The way in which she uses perspective and 
the narrative in her work is steeped in the miniaturist 
traditions and a direct reflection of her background.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Anil Karanjai was a most unusual Indian artist. His technique in pastels is as finely controlled as it is in so many of his oils. What is new is a genuine sense of romance but not entirely at the cost of the surreal element that is ever-present in his work. These pastels did during a rain-soaked monsoon in Dehra Dun, Uttarakhand, stay in the mind; they soothe and caress the senses while retaining their sense of mystery. They celebrate nature with a maturity not seen in Indian landscape painting in a very long time. His work and his conduct seemed to suggest that the landscape of a nation belonged to its people, the poorest of the poor of them and not the microscopic elite that rules over them.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Detailed Description:
A painter who defied classification, Sultan Ali refused to be 
dictated to by the established mores of painting. Rejecting the 
guidelines laid down by European art as too formal and cold, Ali 
turned to the ancient art of folk painting in India for his 
inspiration. Gods and Kings, snakes and bulls, birds and cats 
people his paintings and have come to be identified specifically 
with Ali. He journeyed to Bastar to study the nuances of tribal 
culture and this experience enabled him to fine tune his 
technique and develop a style that came to be known as his own. 
Although any particular form of folk art does not influence his 
works, Sultan Ali's canvases are deeply imbued by folk themes. 
Animals and humans jostle for space on his canvases, sometimes 
even ending up inextricably mixed together.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Born in 1955 in Shillong, Prithpal Ladi studied sculpture at MS 
University, Baroda. Ladi`s works exhibit his penchant for the 
eccentric and strange. They are often condensed narratives in which 
larger than life mechanical devices assume a central position, 
surrounded by limp human figures in postures of obeisance. A more 
direct realism is seen in works like `Wishing Well` and the untitled 
sculpture of a man reading in his bathtub. Ladi infuses his 
sculptures with a queer humor that enables the viewer to access them 
at different levels, moving effortlessly from the familiar to the 
fantastic, or from the apparent to the suggested.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Dignified, reticent, and highly revered, Dinkar Kaushik who was the senior-most contemporary artist, art writer, and teacher had reinvented Kala Bhavan in the 1970s and reshaped it for contemporary art practices. His musician series reflects a close resemblance to the miniature traditions with regard to compositional style and narrativity. This painting shows a drummer, playing on a mrudangam, immersed in the music that emanates from it, while a group of figures appears moving to the rhythm of his drums.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Originally from the Chittagong district of undivided Bengal, 
Sudhir Ranjan Khastgir studied fine arts under Nandalal Bose in 
Kala Bhavana, Santiniketan. He was known for an "Indian style" of 
painting, which began by depicting the beauty of landscapes, 
idealizing toilers of the land, and later creating abstracting 
themes from the mythical and historical past.  He was influenced 
by the Tagore family during his student years at Kala Bhavan, 
Shantiniketan, in its earliest stage. 

Khastigir, later went on to teach at Doon School, Dehra Doon for 
a long period as an art teacher, followed by becoming the 
Principal at Govt. Art College, Lucknow. His visual thematic 
broadly depicted, cheerful dancers, santhals, the Palash flower, 
amaltash trees and the like. Khastgir was also sculptor, and did 
portraits of several eminent Indian and British personalities, 
including Rabindranath Tagore and Jawaharlal Nehru. His 
sculptural compositions include themes from the real as well as 
the mythical world.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Raja Deen Dayal (born 1844 died 1905) was from a middle class 
Jain family from Sardhana near Meerut, U.P. With no formal 
training in photography, and with primitive equipment, Deen Dayal 
went on to become one of India's pioneering 19th century 
photographers. Having opened a commercial studio at Indore in the 
1870's, he worked as official photographer to several viceroys 
including Lord Dufferin and Earl Elgin, before becoming the court 
photographer to Mir Mahboob Ali Khan the sixth Nizam of Hyderabad 
(1866-1911). In 1887 he received the Royal Warrant of appointment 
as photographer to her Majesty, the Queen Victoria.
info.Detailed Description:
His oeuvre of work including many commissions, Royal warrants and 
accolades he received are a testimony to his remarkable 
photographic career in just over three decades. Each image 
reflected a certain degree of aesthetic, subjective, performative 
or 'double entendre' layering, evoking the Deen Dayal essence. 
His composition sense while capturing portraits has been hailed 
as 'far ahead of his time', while his meticulous documentation of 
the British Raj, has left behind a legacy of information and 
history. In 1892, Deen Dayal was conferred the title of 'Musawwir 
Jung Raja Bahadur" or Bold Warrior of Photography, by his patron 
Mir Mahboob Ali Khan. The same year he closed the Indore studio 
and opened a deluxe salon in Mumbai which was mainly run by his 
son Mr.Gyan Chand.

history. In 1892, Deen Dayal was conferred the title of 'Musawwir 
Jung Raja Bahadur" or Bold Warrior of Photography, by his patron 
Mir Mahboob Ali Khan. The same year he closed the Indore studio 
and opened a deluxe salon in Mumbai which was mainly run by his 
son Mr.Gyan Chand.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Raja Deen Dayal (born 1844 died 1905) was from a middle class 
Jain family from Sardhana near Meerut, U.P. With no formal 
training in photography, and with primitive equipment, Deen Dayal 
went on to become one of India's pioneering 19th century 
photographers. Having opened a commercial studio at Indore in the 
1870's, he worked as official photographer to several viceroys 
including Lord Dufferin and Earl Elgin, before becoming the court 
photographer to Mir Mahboob Ali Khan the sixth Nizam of Hyderabad 
(1866-1911). In 1887 he received the Royal Warrant of appointment 
as photographer to her Majesty, the Queen Victoria.
info.Detailed Description:
His oeuvre of work including many commissions, Royal warrants and 
accolades he received are a testimony to his remarkable 
photographic career in just over three decades. Each image 
reflected a certain degree of aesthetic, subjective, performative 
or 'double entendre' layering, evoking the Deen Dayal essence. 
His composition sense while capturing portraits has been hailed 
as 'far ahead of his time', while his meticulous documentation of 
the British Raj, has left behind a legacy of information and 
history. In 1892, Deen Dayal was conferred the title of 'Musawwir 
Jung Raja Bahadur" or Bold Warrior of Photography, by his patron 
Mir Mahboob Ali Khan. The same year he closed the Indore studio 
and opened a deluxe salon in Mumbai which was mainly run by his 
son Mr.Gyan Chand.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A photograph depicting a formal Darbar of His Highness of Bikaner 
Silver Jubilee in 1912. It is interesting to notice a senior 
British officer seated near the king, while an attendant hold a 
bouquet of flowers behind him. The stark difference in attire of 
the soldiers is a striking aspect of this photograph.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A photograph depicting the arrival of Lord Curzon, Viceroy and 
Governor General  of India at Jodhpur in the early 20th Century. We 
see him being officially received by the nobility. The reception is 
at the railway station, the first class compartment forms the 
backdrop to the photograph.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This etching captures the form of a fish through more than just the 
medium. The 'fish' whose form has been etched on the surface, appears 
to be in motion, it has a textured body, and has been located in a 
curious landscape of layers. 
The fish could also be a representation of the self, as a faceless, 
anonymous figure moving through time.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Madhava Menon believed that modernity's savagery on image-making in the 20th century had nothing to do with the 'oriental' spirit he adhered sincerely to. This inevitably had led him to take an ardently anti-modern and hence alienated his position throughout life. his is a neat well-integrated world of beauty, peace, and sanity where man is in perfect harmony with nature which in turn remains clean. Menon's love of Nature, which is indeed his magnificent obsession, is what puts life into his pictures. He is particularly fond of flowers, birds, and trees which he studies minutely and intensely.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Madhava Menon believed that the modernity's savagery on image 
making in 20th century had nothing to do with the 'oriental' 
spirit he adhered sincerely to. This inevitably had led him to 
take ardently anti-modern and hence alienated position through 
out in 
life. his is a neat well-integrated world of beauty, peace and 
sanity where man is in perfect harmony with nature which in turn 
remains clean. Menon's love of Nature, which is indeed his 
magnificent obsession, is what puts life into his pictures. He is 
particularly fond of flowers, birds and trees which he studies 
minutely and intensely.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Mookiah's visual language was premised on folk vocabulary. He was able to communicate it as both monumental and iconic. This is evident in his thematic approach. The iconicity emerges from his dominant engagement with festivals such as jallikattu, folk musicians, and dance forms such as karagattam. Jallikattu happening during Pongal is a sport that pits bulls against humans - Mookiah portrayed the climactic bloody moment signifying synoptically the nature and character of the whole through vibrant gestures and theatrical movements. Mookiah's preferred mediums in sculpture were terracotta and bronze though he worked with different stones. He once remarked, "Talking about my terracotta, I must emphasize, because of the nature of the material, and the ease and freedom it offers, these objects afford an insight into cultural traits, namely the customary mode of expression. In this respect, they are probably of greater value than the impressive monuments in stone."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An artist who was a significant part of the Cholamandal family of 
artists, who broke away from the institutionalized art making and 
formed their own artists village. In this painting as in many 
others, the artists used wax which was often molten on to the 
surface of the canvas, and later removed or cracked in parts. His 
abstractions went beyond the experimentation with form or colour and 
attempted to utilize tactility.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In this varnished water colour the artist has used a style 
inspired by primitivism that is reminiscent of the art of Paul 
Klee. The artist has superimposed the stylized figure of a man at 
the centre of a thick pitted card coloured in a deep red. The 
loose geometry of the body is composed of curved and straight 
coloured lines thus adding an organic feeling to the composition.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Alex Mathews completed post-diploma at M.S. University, Baroda (1982-84), brought figures carved with a fight roughness from the tree, convey a sense of archaic, physical, and emotional unity of people with the organic and animal world. It is a condition of gradual emergence or fluidity seen in the slow, turning rhythms that enclose figures in the material suggesting strong feelings withheld partly. Personal connotations are guessed but not revealed in the images from the borderline of adolescence and adulthood. With love, intimacy, as well as gentle humor, and affirmation the artist, delves into moments of crazy joys, fascinations, innocence, awkward grace and budding eroticism, also grief. The work became more metaphoric in the evocation of human aspirations and fluctuating but tightly bound states or life processes as the wood imbibes the sense of turbulent yet sheltering water, soil rising to the air, and the sun.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Alex Mathews completed post-diploma at M.S. University, Baroda (1982-84), brought figures carved with a fight roughness from the tree, convey a sense of archaic, physical, and emotional unity of people with the organic and animal world. It is a condition of gradual emergence or fluidity seen in the slow, turning rhythms that enclose figures in the material suggesting strong feelings withheld partly.
