info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: The visual imagery of Jagannath Panda's work is deceptively simple: it comprises linear drawing and a rendered form or two, which seem to float on the surface. His drawings are very realistic, yet he does not offer the viewer a reference to the subject's existence, or rather he does not recreate a sense of panorama in his paintings. At times he also employs the use of external material, such as silver foil, thread, tracing sheets, to stress upon the reality of the material. The role of color is limited, though used effectively to highlight form. It also sets off the drawings to their best advantage. Based on his personal experiences, both as a rural migrant and as a city dweller, they represent the artist's projections about the not-so-distant future. As Panda understands them, not only do they involve nature, they are pivoted on the constant tussle between environment and development, nature and technology.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Two Seated birds carved facing each other, joined, attached, and 
united forever, this sculpture is unique in its quality of affect. 
While there is something intimate about the sharing that the birds 
express, there is also a feeling of being made immobile through 
posture in stone, and it is this tension between being bound and 
release that enhances the aesthetic of this sculpture.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In a polluted world of disposable dishes, Arunkumar HG celebrates 
the beauty of reuse found in everyday objects such as metal plates 
that are commonly used in India. As in many of Arunkumar HG's works, 
these sculptures address the disconnect between production, 
consumption and discard in contemporary society. Arunkumar HG 
cleverly sheds light on the often forgotten fact that agrarian labor 
supports and sustains urban and rural societies alike.  The artist 
reflects that "there has been an evolution in materials production 
and use in our lives. I have developed my art making process by 
using materials that do the talking or engage the viewers with their 
own history of being invented, used, reused, abused, or for what 
they are and so on.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Mukherjee used the circ perdu or the lost wax process for her 
sculptures. Deeply influenced by the Dhokra sculptors of Bastar in 
Madhya Pradesh, Mukherjee perfected a technique in bronze that was 
completely her own. Similarly, she evolved an iconography that was 
unique. Opposing pulls of mass and movement, strength and 
vulnerability give an intense character to her figures enhanced by 
the textural play created by the use of decorative elements on the 
surface. Many of Mukherjee's works show the use of Bengali 
calligraphy on the surface. Manifestations of playfulness and whimsy 
often add another dimension to her work.
Mukherjee's work documents the life of the common people, - 
fishermen, weavers, women stitching Kantha, commuters in a crowded 
bus, laborers laying cables and carrying earth.
info.Detailed Description:
Many of her sculptures also relate to music and dance. The energy 
and dynamism of her studies of Baul dancers or the dancing Shiva 
figures have a charged quality that overcomes the limitations of 
metal as a medium. The sense of movement is also seen in her 
sculptures where she visualizes a river as the universe. Two 
elements mark the spirit of Mukherjee's work. One is celebration of 
humanism and two, a yearning for reaching beyond the quotidian and 
rejoicing in freedom and liberation.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Douglas was inclined at first to make abstractions, mathematising his 
paintings with colour formulae, patterns, structure and rhythms.As he 
worked, the picture got dirtier and denser, adverting to the unlit, 
unruly apparition that hung over his vision. The formal devices in 
the painting, the grids, triangles, vertical and horizontal appeared 
so idealistic and unsubtle that they cleared nothing as they spanned 
his pictures. The disorientation, hurt and pain started to register 
in Douglas' painting towards the end of his stay abroad. They were no 
longer painted but stained, scribbled upon, muddied, excessively 
wrought and dense.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Achuthan Kudallur draws upon memories of his childhood and his 
home situated near the river in the town of Kudallur. His 
experience of magical rituals with chanting of mantras, rhythmic 
drumming by firelight, spirit exorcisms, festivals, and kathakali 
dance performances are images that he recapitulates and 
transforms through an abstract vocabulary. Like most painters 
Achuthan began his artistic journey with figurative works, 
including line drawings. He did many illustrations for magazines 
and book covers, which incidentally brought modern art closer to 
readers unfamiliar with the idiom. According to the artist, 
abstraction is a natural extension of figurative work. The 
general sense of ferment that prevailed in the south in those 
years in art and literature facilitated this transition on the 
part of Achuthan.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Anupam Sud brings out the growing friction in a man-woman 
relationship where she shows them sitting close to one another 
but looking in different directions. Are these early signs of a 
crumbling personal relationship or the impossibility of dialogue? 
Her etchings are often satirical comments on the crumbling 
infrastructure of the ever expanding city of Delhi, where the 
ambiguity and uncertainty of urban life spills over into human 
relationships, leading to a collapse of dialogue and connection. 
The dual experience of alienation and belonging is an urban 
phenomenon that creates multiple identities of the self , making 
life a performance through a series of masquerades.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
As an artist Benode Behari was one among the leading art figures 
of pre-Independent India, who saw in Pan-Asianism an invitation 
to explore the linguistic rationale of different traditions. 
Mukherjee led art beyond the dominance of literary subjects and 
mythology, to a form that gave importance to pictorial elements 
such as color, line and texture. In this painting, 'Mother and 
Child', Mukherjee explores the idea of a seated mother with two 
children on either side composed within an outdoor canopy. A 
strong sense of movement and expressivity accompanies this art 
work, as the child poised on his mother's lap gazes outward, and 
outside the visual frame. The earthy colours applied in daubs of 
thick brush strokes, is revealing of a colour palette that
the artist consciously utilized. Initially, Mukherjee drew people 
he saw and 
met around him, but as his vision deteriorated, he moved towards 
the elemental, the bare bones of structures and forms. His 
stylistic development shows his preference for simplicity.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A sensitive artist, Reddy evolved a unique vision of his own, 
creating complex compositions, realistic and expressionistic 
portraits, still-lifes and impressionistic landscapes. His later 
works are abstract, often revealing a tantric influence with folk 
motifs and symbols, and a synthesis of almost contrary forms. As 
an artist, Reddy interprets the traditional Tantra philosophy and 
at the same time deals with contemporary themes. For both neo-
tantric artists and Western modernists, the tension between the 
spiritual and the material found expression through symbols that 
defied particular iconographic or culturally-grounded systems and 
instead evoked broader universal expressions of spirituality, 
patterns in the universe, and sense perception. Reddy's use of 
symbols, connection to a spiritual system in tantra, and 
interpretation of sound all play into similar ideas. 

Reddy came from a poor family of agriculturists, who strongly 
opposed his choice to make art his professional practice. Defying 
his family's wishes, Reddy joined the J. J. School of Arts, 
Bombay to study painting under a scholarship. Here he was also 
trained in mural design and was acquainted with the Rajput and 
Pahari miniature styles.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
As an artist Sham Sunder has always believed that one should 
experiment with new possibilities and innovate new expressions. He is 
a figurative artist working in various mediums like wood, stone and 
wire mesh as a sculptor and also in painting and print making. The 
external physical manifestation of inner turmoil is essential for 
Sham as figurative artist. He also displays a remarkable 
understanding of the risks inherent in easy reductionist approaches 
to issues like individual agony or social collapse. There are no 
sentimental outbursts. Each of his works is carefully executed, 
though at the cost of a certain daring. Sham's works do not provoke 
his viewers, instantly. They haunt them over a period of time. 

Sham's works have emerged as reaction to human relationships, 
violence in society and social evils that go in the name of 
community, culture and tradition.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Jaya represents a generation which confronts contemporary art 
with individuality and daring. Her pictures bring into view her 
own style and she has her own imperatives. In the world of art, 
Jaya's work stands out for its obvious concern with the 
aesthetics in art rather than commercial success. Jaya works with 
broad and sure brush strokes done in a spectrum of rich colors. 
The sure color strokes stand out and her work evokes the feeling 
that the world is full of organic tones that seem to breathe with 
a life force of its own. 

The figures look massive and primitive, voluminous and these 
qualities give her figures a distinctive character. Dark men and 
women sitting in a closed world of their own seem to brood, 
looking into themselves with an enigmatic air. Her figures have 
structural compositional values and they seem to be full of 
tension and force. An element of surprise in her work is the 
quasi-abstract quality. Black and indigo add dynamism and 
highlight the work. Jaya says her paintings are a strand of 
thought.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Bose`s paintings characterize vibrant colours and the play of 
light and shade. His inspiration comes from the Poet Laureate, 
Rabindranath Tagore. "My canvases do not tell a story. Neither 
are they a reflection of society and its myriad complexities nor 
are they abstract images that are open to interpretation. They 
are simply things of beauty. I just record all that the eye sees 
and the memory retains," says Bose.
Based on his moods, the artist`s paintings capture the fleeting 
memories that are retained in the mind. The sun pouring in 
through an open window, lighting up the interiors; the image of a 
wall that has developed lines, which form a delicate tracery, and 
the figures of birds roosting on a balcony - all these are grist 
to his mill.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painting that resembles a reflection of the artist himself - we see 
an indoor scene depicted in bright colours and pen lines. The red 
table and the walls stand out as striking in comparison to the 
stripes that are drawn on the surface of all the other objects. On 
the table, placed in the middle of the table is a head that at first 
sight appears to rise from the body of the table. On closer 
inspection, one sees that it is a lifeless bust of a head, perhaps a 
souvenir part of the many knick-knacks scattered around this room, 
that shows character of an artist studio.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: A portrait of a renowned play-write, this painting shows Basheer, sitting shirtless on his easy chair, perhaps in the afternoon sun, smoking a cigarette. The artist has captured the moment evocatively, where the simplicity of this literary figure has been portrayed. In his left hand are his spectacles, while sheets of a paper lie spread out beside him. Basheer appears to be taking a break from his writing when the artist decided to paint him.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Saitha Shankar's art explores the female body and self in 
manifold ways and by bringing in elements of desire and fantasy, 
employing realist, impressionist, surrealist and abstract modes 
in specifically Indian ways. She said "To hold conviction in my 
own mind a work must begin to ask questions to me about our very 
existence. I believe, therefore, that when the dialogue between a 
work of art and the artist is deep-rooted, the presence of the 
artist in that work is ever-present." In 1984, she travelled to 
Santiniketan and during that visit met Mr. K.G. Subramaniam. She 
was much impressed by his work and his overall approach to art. 
Another artist who has held particular importance for her is 
K.C.S. Panicker whose early works such as "Humanity", she was 
drawn to since she was a student. She says "What I want to show 
in my work is the idea that hides itself behind so called 
reality."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A sculpture that is entwined with religious iconography, this artwork 
creates a parallel to the 'lingam', an aniconic form that is 
worshiped in the Hindu religion. With some wit and with raw 
intensity, this image play on an embodied comparison of a bird's 
dynamic alertness and the male organ, while the surface, in a rough-
fluid manner, blends a feel of skin and vegetal or earth texture.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
K.C.S.Panicker was both an influential art teacher, having 
retired as principal of the Government College of Arts and Crafts 
Chennai, as well as an innovative painter heralding the birth of 
Modernism in South India. He influences and inspired a number of 
artists of the younger generation not only through his seminal 
works and experimentation but also through the conception of 
Cholamandal , a self-sufficient artists village,. He broke away 
from figurative art leading the compositions towards form. The 
neat scribbles and cryptic encounter with the notebook of a 
student of mathematics, an element of Tantra was slowly ushered 
in mainly because of their play of astrological looking diagrams 
and calligraphy. There is also the piquancy of the folk motif, 
which acts as the catalyst in the composition.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting appears to abstract the figural with animal forms. The 
colours although bright appear dulled out to give a textured feel. 
The artist is perhaps expressing the interconnectedness between 
animal and human worlds, or making a statement very specific to her 
context. The direction of the gazes makes for an interesting 
composition, where one looks directly at the viewer, the figural face 
along with the bird positioned looking away.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A mixed media artwork that revisits the portrait of Mona Lisa through 
a contemporary lens, this image shows the eyes of the Bollywood 
actress Kajol, placed on an outline sketch, made to resemble the 
famous portrait of Mona Lisa. The image in question however is burqa 
clad, that in todays communally polarized world gives a new twist to 
this meaning of Mona Lisa and the image of femininity.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Leela Tyagi of Tajpur in Bijnore, UP has worked steadily and 
consistently for a number of years. After a stint at Art 
College, she continued her journey in Art at Triveni Kala 
Sangam, New Delhi. The head of the Art Department then, was 
Rameshwar Broota - an eminent and distinguished Artist. She 
then moved to Bangalore in South India, where she is presently 
based in Bangalore.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Vasudev's art revealed the main aspects of the Cholamandal 
aesthetic. Although change is an important aspect of his work, it 
is always held tight by an inherent consistency. The Vriksha has 
been central to Vasudev's artistic vision. In the early years of 
the Vriksha series, the canvas was thickly encrusted with swirls 
of paint, as if the tree itself were growing out of the canvas. 
The early influence of F.N Souza's expressionism had soon 
dissolved though Palsikar's philosophical attitude would remain. 
By 1969 I had completely got rid of impastos and my forms were 
very free at the time. With the brush itself I would create 
texture.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A well-reputed artist whose pattern paintings are well known for 
their colours and coming together of geometric shapes. Combining 
abstraction of lines and geometric shapes along with colour, Sahani 
creates a stain glass like effect with many of his painting. In this 
painting the use of perspective has been abstracted to give the 
feeling of three dimensionality and movement.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Joydip Sengupta's artistic discourse is deeply and evocatively 
political, but his art is truly painterly. His works reflect a 
study of the dynamic process of the transformation and 
perpetuation of signs and images in a constantly evolving post-
colonial environment. Joydip Sengupta's search for identity, 
individual and artistic both, fuelled by a sense of alienation, 
began during his stay in Scotland on a Commonwealth Fellowship. 
This encouraged him to explore his creative roots for a uniquely 
Indian worldview and sensibility. It is no wonder that much of 
his work is concerned with issues of identity - of race, religion 
and region - mediated through a symbology of myths and icons. 

As an artist who works by reference, Joydip derives his painterly 
devices from pre-existing images as diverse as Kalighat paintings 
to Indian philosophical texts.This informs much of his earlier 
works where concepts such as Chinmasta, based on Indian myths, 
are dominant. His current engrossment is with the insidious 
effects of globalisation - leading not only to erosion of 
cultural heterogeneity but also to economic and regional 
marginalisation, in the guise of religion or democracy.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Dhiraj Choudhury's work should classify as dynamic and line-based 
choreography. His restless line speaks volumes both in drawing as 
well as painting.His several portfolios of Drawings, some done 
abroad during his overseas travels, are a gem of art to be 
preserved for posterity. His paintings could well attract the 
epithet of "Saga".
 They are telling narratives on the contemporary situation - 
social as well as political. His characters defy tradition or 
iconographic nicities. They are provocative and ever more agile, 
bestowed with a pinching sense of humour, Dhiraj Choudhary makes 
his audience sit up and participate in the activity introduced in 
the picture space.
Indeed, Dhiraj Choudhary makes his audience peer and prawl, not 
just for a moment, but ad infinitum. Dhiraj Choudhary's art 
challenges one at every step, every moment of one's viewing. And 
gosh! How much of agility and agitation he infuses in his 
pictorial statement - the narratives of the human dynamism and 
perseverance. Dhiraj treats his picture frame as a stage, just 
about to witness a soul-shaking, nerve-ratting play. No pensive 
moods or pacifist situation for Dhiraj Choudhury.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
"The wash watercolor technique, that I use, makes the subject 
blend gently with the background as boundaries melt away, 
creating an effect that is mysterious and alluring." Mukherjee 
successfully integrated Western modernism with Eastern sublimity 
and mysteriousness, a style perfected by the Neo-Bengal School, 
to which he belonged. Though his style was very definitely 
Cubist, at least in his later works, with the help of the wash 
watercolor technique, he managed to imbue his canvases with a 
deep sense of relaxation. So dedicated was Mukherjee to the wash 
watercolor technique, that he never deviated to other mediums 
like oil or graphics. He explored all possible combinations of 
the technique, applying it to themes ranging from `Devi` images 
to expressionistic and sternly futuristic abstractions. His most 
famous works have been landscapes; he hardly tempered them with 
the use of white, which is very common in landscape paintings.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A narrative painting that tells the story of the two young 
boys Luv & Kush, the sons of Rama, who unknowingly fought 
against their own father's army. The painting eloquently 
depicts the Rishi Valmiki in deep meditation, Sita sitting 
indoors longing for Rama while the battle with Luv and Kush 
can be seen in progress, in the foreground. On the left corner 
is the stallion that is tied by Luv and Kush, resulting in the 
battle between the children and their father's army. We can 
also see monkeys watching the battle, while many of the army 
men are in a state of sleep by the power of the children. The 
painting as a whole forms an elegant continuous narrative of one 
incident.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This drawing shows a male figure on horseback holding a long 
stick-like object in his right hand and the reigns of the horse 
in the other. In front of him are five men presenting themselves 
to the emperor with outstretched arms. One of the men in the 
centre appears to be a 
prisoner as his hands are bound and a chain is tied to his neck. 
Three of the other men carry swords, shields and one even has a 
mace suggesting they are soldiers. This drawing appears to be the 
preparatory drawing for a painting as the artist has begun 
painting a red colour on one of the caps, seen here on the head 
of one of the soldiers.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An outline sketch of a regimental man riding a horse, this sketch 
effectively captures movement and the stoic position of the officer.
A sword is visible in the man hand, while the horse has one foot 
lifted as if in motion. From the varying thickness of the line, this 
appears to be a preliminary outline sketch done prior to the filling 
of colour.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A typical painting of the Company period, probably painted by an 
officer of the gentry. It depicts a European woman lying against 
a red pillow, watching a bid that seems to fly around her. An 
imaginary pose, resembling English portraitist style of work 
around the 18th century, this painting also has been composed in 
an oval shape, a common feature of art making during this period.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This drawing shows a young man in profile view. In his left hand 
he holds a bunch of flowers and appears to be smelling them. 
Around his waist is a red-striped cloth tied like a bow 
symbolizing his royal stature. 
One of his feet are lifted off the ground suggesting movement 
signifying that the young man was probably walking. From the 
turban and the attire of this man, it can be assumed that he is a 
prince most likely of the Mughal dynasty.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This exceptional portrait of Ranjit Singh, shows him facing the 
viewer, in three-fourth view. The portrait reveals the artist's 
skill of academic drawing, as the techniques of perspective, and 
three dimensionality has been demonstrated. Unlike other 
portraits of Ranjith Singh, this painting evokes a more humane 
character, with no heroism or pride, but sitting, smiling, in a 
very comfortable way, revealing a domestic ambiance. While the 
costume, jewelry and iconography of a ruler has been shown, it is 
the posture and facial features that bring out a calmer, more 
grounded character to this portrait.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The painting depicts a seated man, who has on his head a 
bejeweled crown with a white feather on the finial. He holds a 
sword in his right hand with the same elbow resting on a 'deewan' 
or long cushion. He has a green necklace and has been painted in-
doors. Red curtains and an archway can be seen in the background. 
Titled the 'last Mughal emperor', this figure could be Aurangzeb.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This glass painting is a portrait of an emperor. His ornate 
turban, finger rings, and shoulder bands signify his royal 
stature. In his hands he holds a black object that appears to be 
an arrow as a bow can be seen clutched between his right arm. The 
emperor is clothed in a green robe with gold spots. He has a long 
beard as well as a prominent mustache. The figure has no eyeball 
in his right eye. This could either be an incomplete painting or 
it could have been lost due to damage.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In this painting we see a child that resembles Krishna, sitting 
on the lap of his mother Yashoda. Krishna has in his right hand a 
peacock feather while he clings onto a necklace with his left 
hand. Yashoda sits with one leg lifted and her left arm resting 
on her left thigh. At her foot is a green cushion that resembles 
the green of the background.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An elegant portrait of a woman with a dog, this painting depicts 
a reclined nude woman, adorned with inlaid jewels. A noteworthy 
element of this style of portrait painting, is the close 
resemblance of both the woman's features as well as the inlaid 
stone work, to early Tanjore painting. The woman in the painting 
appears seated indoors, on a diwan, and a large curtain forms the 
backdrop.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An early Deccani style of portrait painting can be recognized in 
this portrait of a Maratha Woman. Her appears seated, and is 
looking towards the viewer. Close attention has been paid to her 
attire, a traditional saree, and the ornaments that adorn her. An 
interesting aspect is the representation of more than two arms to 
her body, which could be the artist's depiction of her divine 
status.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Originally from the Chittagong district of undivided Bengal, 
Sudhir Ranjan Khastgir studied fine arts under Nandalal Bose in 
Kala Bhavana, Santiniketan. He was known for an "Indian style" of 
painting, which began by depicting the beauty of landscapes, 
idealizing toilers of the land, and later creating abstracting 
themes from the mythical and historical past.  He was influenced 
by the Tagore family during his student years at Kala Bhavan, 
Shantiniketan, in its earliest stage. 

Khastigir, later went on to teach at Doon School, Dehra Doon for 
a long period as an art teacher, followed by becoming the 
Principal at Govt. Art College, Lucknow. His visual thematic 
broadly depicted, cheerful dancers, santhals, the Palash flower, 
amaltash trees and the like. Khastgir was also sculptor, and did 
portraits of several eminent Indian and British personalities, 
including Rabindranath Tagore and Jawaharlal Nehru. His 
sculptural compositions include themes from the real as well as 
the mythical world.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
There is of course colour and subtle tonal and compositional 
variations, moving towards making an impressive statement. For 
Kalicharan Gupta's imagery is complex and demands exploration. This 
exploration is both visual as well as architectural (structural, that 
is). Gupta's works engage you both in contrast and harmony. Painted 
in a semi abstract style, his works invite you to view and weigh the 
impact of the urban landscape. Delhi born Kalicharan Gupta has 
concerned himself with urban life and urban landscape. His earlier 
"Everyone doing his or her own thing" got transmuted into the 
urban/metropolitan high rise and its visual impact.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Shabir Hassan's abstract paintings range from religion to social 
issues, which does tend to shake ones thoughts.  One of the most 
striking things in his works is that it not only indicates 
imagination and creativity of the artist but speaks great volumes of 
the philosophy that guides his brush and colours.  

While retaining Indian values, influences and aspirations, Hassan has 
absorbed world developments and social changes in his work.  Artistic 
progression from realism to abstraction can be easily seen in the 
abstract paintings produced by Hassan. An avid student of art history 
and music, Hassan feels that his faith in Sufism has also played a 
major role in his work.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Hyder Ali was the sultan and de facto ruler of the Kingdom of 
Mysore in southern India. Though illiterate, Hyder Ali earned an 
important place in the history of southern India for his 
administrative acumen and military skills. This print of Hyder 
Ali, the father of Tipu Sultan, depicts the king, dressed in a 
soldier's uniform. He looks directly at the viewer, dressed in a 
red armor-like outfit that closely resembles a French soldier 
uniform. On his head is a turban from which a large feather is 
worn, expressing his royal status. Hyder Ali concluded an 
alliance with the French against the British, and used the 
services of French workmen in raising his artillery and arsenal.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A detailed portrait of a seated woman, depicting her attire as an 
iconography element of her ethnicity. She wears her saree pallu 
over her head, symbolizing her religious background; a person of 
Islamic faith. Her hands are adorned with bangles, while a 
vertical bindi, an unusual factor of muslim women, can be seen on 
her forehead. Her jewelry and the throne-like chair on which she 
appears seated, reflect her status, which may have been that of 
the nobility.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
An artist who painted numerous portraits, Jagdish Chandra attempted 
to represent form through colour and a minimalist visual language. 
While many of his portraits resemble the drip technique, he also 
works with simplified shapes like swirls, strokes, drip, dots to 
create a larger image. This painting titled 'After Image', attempts 
to look beyond the represented face into the image that a face leaves 
behind within the mind of the viewer.
info.Detailed Description:
Jagdish studied painting from Delhi College of Arts, University of 
Delhi (1972-77) and in 1984-86 went to the Department of Fine Arts, 
University of Tsukuba, Japan as a Research Scholar. He has won awards 
and scholarships like Junior Fellowship in painting from Ministry of 
Human Resources & Development, Scholarship in painting, University of 
Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan awarded by the  Japanese Govt. (Monbusho), 
Sahitya Kala Parishad Award in Painting,Delhi; Sanskriti Award in  
the field of art by Sanskriti Pratisthan, Delhi 1988, National Award 
in painting, National Lalit Kala Academy, Delhi 1990, Senior 
Fellowship in Fine Arts from Ministry of Human Resources and 
Development 1996-98. Has held many solo exhibitions and been part of 
many group shows like Power of Peace, Imprints (Ueno Royal Museum, 
Tokyo),Indiart 2007 at The House of Lords, London to name a few.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
The artist appears to have juxtaposed geometric shapes of triangles 
and squares along with contemporary symbols, like that of a bulb 
connoting an idea. The shapes also appear to reference the pattern of 
inter-connected shapes drawn as a decorative element in front of many 
Indian homes. The background of a textured brown also adds a floor-
like quality to the painting.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This etching appears to form a navigative experience, like that of a 
map. While the most striking element is the grey-green triangle located 
centrally across the etching, the intricately made background of 
convoluted pathways and little demarcations form a geographical 
landscape, perhaps of a civilization.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Kolte's abstract layering with paint echo cityscapes where the signs 
and textures reveal his modernist consciousness. Bands of color 
juxtaposed against each other create bold ascensions and recessions.
info.Detailed Description:
Prabhakar Kolte was born in 1946 and received his diploma from the 
Sir J.J. School of Art in 1968. Between 1972 and 1994 he taught at 
the School of Art. He has had several solo shows and participated in 
important group exhibitions like 'Art- Mosaic- celebration of 
Calcutta's Tercentenary, Calcutta and Mumbai, 1990; 'Wounds' CIMA 
Gallery, Calcutta, 1993; 'Parallel Perceptions' Sakshi, Gallery, 
Mumbai, 1993 and 94 and 'Bombay- A Tribute To The City' organized by 
RPG Enterprises, Mumbai, 1995. Kolte has also exhibited at 'Six 
Indian Painters' curated by Geeta Kapur at Toto grad, Yugoslavia, 
Ankara and Istanbul, 1985, 'Three Artists' Hong Kong, 1995 and 
Galerie Foundation for Indian Artists, Amsterdam, 1996.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Sajitha Shankar's art explores the female body and self in manifold ways and by bringing in elements of desire and fantasy, employing realist, impressionist, surrealist, and abstract modes in specifically Indian ways. She said "To hold conviction in my own mind a work must begin to ask questions to me about our very existence. I believe, therefore, that when the dialogue between a work of art and the artist is deep-rooted, the presence of the artist in that work is ever-present." In 1984, she traveled to Santiniketan and during that visit met Mr. K.G. Subramaniam. She was much impressed by his work and his overall approach to art. Another artist who has held particular importance for her is K.C.S. Panicker whose early works such as "Humanity", she was drawn to since she was a student. She says "What I want to show in my work is the idea that hides behind so-called reality.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Saitha Shankar's art explores the female body and self in 
manifold ways and by bringing in elements of desire and fantasy, 
employing realist, impressionist, surrealist and abstract modes 
in specifically Indian ways. She said "To hold conviction in my 
own mind a work must begin to ask questions to me about our very 
existence. I believe, therefore, that when the dialogue between a 
work of art and the artist is deep-rooted, the presence of the 
artist in that work is ever-present."  In 1984, she travelled to 
Santiniketan and during that visit met Mr. K.G. Subramaniam. She 
was much impressed by his work and his overall approach to art. 
Another artist who has held particular importance for her is 
K.C.S. Panicker whose early works such as "Humanity", she was 
drawn to since she was a student. She says "What I want to show 
in my work is the idea that hides itself behind so called 
reality."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Saitha Shankar's art explores the female body and self in 
manifold ways and by bringing in elements of desire and fantasy, 
employing realist, impressionist, surrealist and abstract modes 
in specifically Indian ways. She said "To hold conviction in my 
own mind a work must begin to ask questions to me about our very 
existence. I believe, therefore, that when the dialogue between a 
work of art and the artist is deep-rooted, the presence of the 
artist in that work is ever-present."  In 1984, she travelled to 
Santiniketan and during that visit met Mr. K.G. Subramaniam. She 
was much impressed by his work and his overall approach to art. 
Another artist who has held particular importance for her is 
K.C.S. Panicker whose early works such as "Humanity", she was 
drawn to since she was a student. She says "What I want to show 
in my work is the idea that hides itself behind so called 
reality."

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Rajendran's work is an assemblage of techniques and disparate 
materials collapsing the conventional materials such as wood, 
clay and stone. The tactility of his meticulously crafted objects 
compels the viewer to experience the comfort and suffering, 
pleasure and unease simultaneously. He tackles diverse issues 
such as militarism, ecological and urban atrocities within the 
contexts of Indian city life. He juxtaposes the contradictions, 
contrary values and social apathy towards it where, for example, 
he addresses the sacred and the profane on the same level using 
ceramic tiles, boxes, leather and iron. Sumedh uses industrial 
materials while giving them an aesthetic value.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
"I don't draw a pattern on paper and ask someone else to design it. 
What you see is what I have made from scratch," she says. Latika 
Katt's works are defined by minute detailing as well as an 
overwhelming presence of nature. "Metal casting," she says, "is like 
an unborn child, you don't know what it will look like till it is 
delivered/ cast." Possessing the uncanny ability of getting 'under 
the skin' of her subjects, to look at it from deep within, she ends 
up creating infinite crevices and intriguing details.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Hema Upadhyay's work speaks strongly of the metropolis of Mumbai 
- the issues such as migrations, dislocation, multi-cultural 
aspects of the city are very much part of her work.  Her recent 
work conjures up an image of a world that exists literally below 
the surface, is mysterious, invisible and carries intimations 
about secrets and lies, about romance and violence. Hema brings 
forth her own artistic resolutions by re-positioning the self-
portrait in a larger social, cultural milieu. Hema's works in 
gouache, acrylic, graphite and photographs on paper continue her 
creative engagement with the hopes and exigencies of urban 
living.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A painter, illustrator, tutor and writer, Paritosh Sen has been a 
part of the world of Indian art, for close to four decades now. 
Founder of the Calcutta Group in the 1940s, prior to the 
existence of a Progressive Artists group, his art is rendered 
from a cynical and detached perspective, which is typically Sen's 
viewpoint. His style of representation is influenced by his 
exposure to 
Western Modern art, and has traces of cubism. He 
uses two dimensional, structured planes but still creates an 
illusion of voluptuousness. The human figure dominates Sen's 
artwork and recurrent subject in Sen's works is his depiction of 
scenes from everyday urban life.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Reena Saini Kallat is an artist wholly absorbed by the never-ending 
cycle of nature, and the fragility of the human condition in its 
hands. All of her works, whether installations, photographs, 
paintings or sculptures, reflect the constant shifts between building 
and collapsing movements, birth, death and rebirth and defeat and 
resurgence. There seems no greater inspiration in her works than the 
undefeatable and un-fatigable 'prakriti,' or nature. A force that is 
constantly creating and destroying, never resting as one world 
replaces another, only to end eventually itself. Kallat gives the 
mundane a surreal twist, when she paints cars and houses in filled 
balloons, or towering structures made out of slices of bread faced by 
androgynous and fantastic creatures. "Balloons are fragile so putting 
these aspirational things inside them is a way of putting across how 
ephemeral are the objects we most chase," she says.
info.Detailed Description:
Kallat graduated from the Sir J.J. School of Art in 1996, and belongs 
to the new generation of Indian artists who have successfully 
reinterpreted and given a new facet to abstract art. In one of her 
more recent installations, a part of the 2002 Kala Ghoda Art Fest, 
she used beach sand to create seven uterine forms on the floor 
representative of the seven islands that came together to make the 
city of Mumbai. This piece, called the 'Seven Faces of Dust,' once 
again represents the transitory nature of all the things we long for, 
and of our momentary lives as well - it is to be effaced after the 
showing, and the sand returned to the beach. 

Reena also trained as a Bharatanatyam dancer for eight years, but as 
it turned out, painting was her calling and foremost love. She 
recalls her first showing - that of some poster colours she painted 
when she was in class IX. Kallat held her fist professional solo show 
called ' Orchards of Homegrown Secrets' in Mumbai, 1998, and has 
since held many more exhibitions of her work. Kallat has also been 
the recipient of several notable honours, including the Gladstone 
Solomon Award for painting.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Amina's artistic pursuits took a new turn towards non-figurative 
expression and geometric composition when she trained for a time 
under Caesar Domela, a close associate of the Dutch 
abstractionist Piet Mondrian, with whom he founded the De Stijl 
group.
During the years of her reclusive existence, however, Amina kept 
up her interest in abstract art and did a variety of works that 
was more in the nature of experimental essays, often left 
unfinished. The creative output seems to speak of the turbulent 
mind of an artist who led her life in the twilight world of the 
figurative and the non-figurative, each seeking to get the better 
of the other in terms of complementarity and contrast. The 
fluidity of both her pen-and-ink figurations and complex brush-
strokes should be seen and understood as such - as random 
scratches on a lacerated mind seeking desperately to bridge the 
visible and the invisible.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Born in 1936 Rajendra Dhawan studied at the Delhi School of 
Art 
from 1953-58, and at Belgrade from 1960-62. He had founded a 
group "The Unknown" which held shows from 1960-64. Has held 
several exhibitions of his work in India and Europe. His 
colour-scapes are almost always in sepia, creating a somber 
earthy tactility.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
A water colour painting, titled 'Bosom Friends', this painting 
is a remarkable representation of intimacy and closeness 
between two women. The visual of two embracing women, with one 
seated on the others' lap clutching her hand. Her posture, 
with her legs slightly parted ad positioning of her neck shows 
a visible comfort and intimacy between the two women. To 
emphasize the attraction, a television located on a table in 
front of the couple also has on its screen a couple engrossed 
in each other, their eyes almost literally interlocked. Above 
the Television is a frames portrait also of a couple getting 
intimate. Located entirely indoors and painted in a distinctly 
Kalighat path like technique, this visual poses questions 
around intimacy sharing and physical needs.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: Sunayani Devi, considered a primitivist, was born to a family of talented writers and painters. Her uncle was Rabindranath Tagore and her older brothers were Abanindranath and Gaganendranath. From the start her paintings have been considered bold, original, resembling ancient Jain paintings in their hieratic quality. While her initial style was very similar to Abanindranath's, employing the wash technique to its fullest, her later paintings, reflected ideation arising from the encounter with village clay dolls that often adorned urban homes, and Kalighat pats. The modernist discourse of primitive simplicity and the nationalist discourse of cultural authenticity come together in the image of Sunayani Devi as a nationalist artist.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description: The artist strives to escape from the social framework, and at the same time, tries to collect scattered fragments of daily life. Through the process of editing and applying these (fragments), he superimposes various facets of contemporary society. In fact, though formally trained as a painter, Shetty progressively became interested in sculpture and installation and began to combine his paintings with found objects that he painted. In 1996 he attended a sculpture workshop in Scotland that resulted in a spontaneous showing of swiftly executed watercolors; sketches in which the predominant leitmotif was that of a carrier bag embellished by whimsical images and memories of the surroundings. His art world reflects contemporary urban life. By stimulating the memories of people's childhood and their playful-mind filled with curiosity, he cleverly escapes from the globalism that homogenizes the world and innocently plots to overthrow the value system led by politics and the economy.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
In 1993, with the fame of Madhuri Dixit, whose dance numbers 
choreographed by Saroj Khan became an overnight sensation 
Dayanita Singh convinced The Independent newspaper to send her to 
Mumbai to photograph Khan, known as Masterji in the industry. The 
result is one of the most charming, though little-known, series 
of photographs, "Masterji Series", around legendary Bollywood 
choreographer Saroj Khan.  
The artist said "Back then, I did not have the means to buy more 
than 20 rolls of film, so I had to be careful about selecting the 
shots I would take." Singh trailed Khan tirelessly, for all the 
three shifts she was doing each day, and waited for the right 
moments.
info.Detailed Description:
Dayanita Singh considers herself 'a bookmaker working with 
photography', and has often referred to her photographs as 
'words', that she arranges and rearranges into different 
narratives. Although Singh now owns a digital camera and uses it, 
she prefers film and its inbuilt constraints-or advantages, 
depending on the way one looks at it. "The difference between 
using digital and analogue forms is akin to typing on computers 
and writing longhand," she says. The latter slows down time, 
allowing for reflection rather than impulse.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Part of a larger set of architectural drawings, these digital prints 
depict various buildings of Imperial Delhi. The original blueprints 
were hand-drawn on various medium like cloth, and paper, showing 
exquisite eye for detail. They have also been coloured in parts to 
delineate areas of staircases, pillars, and walls made of red stone. 

Other works from the larger collection were displayed in an 
exhibition titled 'Dawn Upon Delhi', which included engravings, maps, 
plans, vintage and modern photographs of Delhi as well as the British 
strongholds of Bombay and Calcutta. Amongst the priceless drawings 
that were exhibited was a hand-drawn and signed map of the imperial 
bungalows of old Delhi by British architect Edwin Lutyens, the 
master-planner of the capital city between 1912 and 1930.

These blueprints are digital reprints, the originals are in the 
possession of the Central Public Works Department.

In the 1960s and 1970s he was the chief organiser of the activities of

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
Caur's work responds to the surroundings and events of her life, from 
the crowded Patel Nagar of her childhood to events such as the rape 
of Maya Tyagi and the widows of the Chasnala mining disaster. 
Punjabi literature influenced Caur's artistic perspective, and 
writers such as Shiv Batalvi, Amrita Pritam, and Krishna Sobti were 
visitors to her home. The literature and philosophy of Punjab 
contributed to the strains of melancholy, mysticism and devotion that 
may be felt in her work, while the Pahari miniature tradition 
provided inspiration for Caur's manipulation of pictorial space. The 
repeated motif of clothing in Caur's work both confirms and subverts 
the traditional picture of women.

info.Museum Name: National Gallery of Modern Art, Bengaluru
info.Brief Description:
This painting by V.Ramesh is part of a larger series painted for an 
exhibition titled Remembrances of Voices Past. This exhibition 
brought together largely allegorical painting that echo the voices of 
three iconic women saints; Karaikal Amma, Akka Mahadevi and Lal Ded . 
These voices find expression through the literal, in the form of 
poetry, and symbolic in the artist's utilization of shapes and 
elaborately textured surfaces. Ramesh's paintings have a deeply 
personal quality about them, and their dialogue with faith and 
devotion form the points of connect.
